encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Wife 2. Wife 3. Wife 2. Citizen 3. Citizen 1 Servant 2 Servant

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

body.stage: Enter King Frederick, Sorano, Valerio, Camillo, Cleanthes, Menallo, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Will your Grace speak?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Let me alone Sorano,
Although my thoughts seem sad, they are welcome to me.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: You know I am private as your secret wishes,
Ready to fling my soul upon your service,
Ere your command be on it.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Bid those depart.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: You must retire my Lords.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What new design is hammering in his head now?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Let us pray heartily
None of our heads meet with it, my wife is old,
That is all my comfort.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Mine is ugly, that I am sure on,
And I think honest too, it would make me start else.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Mine is troubled in the Country with a fever,
And some few infirmities else; he looks again,
Come let us retire, certain it is some she business,
This new Lord is employed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will not be far off, because I doubt the cause.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Are they all gone?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: All but your faithful servant.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I would tell thee,
But it is a thing thou canst not like.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Pray ye speak it, is it my head? I have it ready for ye, Sir:
Is it any action in my power? my wit?
I care not of what nature, nor what follows.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I am in love.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: That is the least thing of a thousand,
The easiest to achieve.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: But with whom Sorano?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: With whom you please, you must not be denied, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Say it be with one of thy Kinswomen.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Say withal,
I shall more love your Grace, I shall more honour ye,
And would I had enough to serve your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Fred/
sp.l: Why it is thy Sister then, the fair Evanthe,
I will be plain with thee.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: I will be as plain with you Sir,
She brought not her perfections to the world,
To lock them in a case, or hang them by her,
The use is all she breeds them for, she is yours, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fed.
sp.l: Dost thou mean seriously?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: I mean my Sister,
And if I had a dozen more, they were all yours:
Some Aunts I have, they have been handsome women,
My mother is dead indeed, and some few cozens
That are now shooting up, we shall see shortly.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No, it is Evanthe.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: I have sent my man unto her,
Upon some business to come presently
Hither, she shall come; Your Grace dare speak unto her?
Large golden promises, and sweet language, Sir,
You know what they work, she is a complete Courtier,
Besides I will set in.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She weights upon my Queen,
What jealousy and anger may arise,
Incensing her?

sp.speaker: Sora.
sp.l: You have a good sweet Lady,
A woman of so even and still a temper,
She knows not anger; say she were a fury,
I had thought you had been absolute the great King,
The fountain of all honours, plays and pleasures,
Your will and your commands unbounded also,
Go get a pair of beads and learn to pray, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: My Lord, your servant stays.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Bid him come hither, and bring the Lady with him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I will woo her,
And either lose myself, or win her favour.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: She is coming in.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Thy eyes shoot through the door,
They are so piercing, that the beams they dart
Give new light to the room.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Whether dost thou go?
This is the Kings side, and his private lodgings,
What business have I here?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: My Lord sent for ye.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: His lodgings are below, you are mistaken,
We left them at the stair-foot.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: Good sweet Madam,

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I am no Counsellor, nor important Suitor.
Nor have no private business through these Chambers,
To seek him this way, on my life thou art drunk,
Or worse than drunk, hired to convey me hither
To some base end; now I look on thee better,
Thou hast a bawdy face, and I abhor thee,
A beastly bawdy face, I will go no further.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Nay shrink not back, indeed you shall good Sister,
Why do you blush? the good King will not hurt ye,
He honours ye, and loves ye.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Is this the business?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Yes, and the best you ever will arrive at, if you be wise.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: My Father was no bawd Sir,
Nor of that worshipful stock as I remember.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: You are a fool.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: You are that I shame to tell ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Gentle Evanthe.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: The gracious Queen Sir
Is well and merry, heaven be thanked for it,
And as I think she waits you in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let her wait there, I talk not of her Garden,
I talk of thee sweet flower.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Your Grace is pleasant,
To mistake a nettle for a rose.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No Rose, nor Lily, nor no glorious Hyacinth
Are of that sweetness, whiteness, tenderness,
Softness, and satisfying blessedness
As my Evanthe.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Your Grace speaks very feelingly,
I would not be a handsome wench in your way Sir,
For a new gown.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou art all handsomeness,
Nature will be ashamed to frame another
Now thou art made, thou hast robbed her of her cunning,
Each several part about thee is a beauty.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Do you hear this Sister?

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Yes unworthy Brother, but all this will not do.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: But love Evanthe,
Thou shalt have more than words, wealth, ease, and honours
My tender wench.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Be tender of my credit,
And I shall love you Sir, and I shall honour ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I love thee to enjoy thee my Evanthe,
To give thee the content of love.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Hold, hold Sir, ye are too fleet,
I have some business this way, your Grace can never content.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: You stubborn toy.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Good my Lord Bawd I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou shalt not go, believe me sweet Evanthe,
So high I will advance thee for this favour,
So rich and potent I will raise thy fortune,
And thy friends mighty.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Good your Grace be patient,
I shall make the worst honourable wench that ever was,
Shame your discretion, and your choice.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou shalt not.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Shall I be rich do you say, and glorious,
And shine above the rest, and scorn all beauties,
And mighty in command?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou shalt be anything.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Let me be honest too, and then I will thank ye.
Have you not such a title to bestow too?
If I prove otherwise, I would know but this Sir;
Can all the power you have or all the riches,
But tie men's tongues up from discoursing of me,
Their eyes from gazing at my glorious folly,
Time that shall come from wondering at my impudence,
And they that read my wanton life from curses?
Can you do this? have ye this magic in ye?
This is not in your power, though you be a Prince Sir,
No more than evil is in holy Angels,
Nor I, I hope; get wantonness confirmed
By Act of Parliament an honesty,
And so received by all, I will hearken to ye.
Heaven guide your Grace.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Evanthe, stay a little,
I will no more wantonness,I will marry thee.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: What shall the Queen do?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I will be divorced from her.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Can you tell why? what has she done against ye?
Has she contrived a treason against your Person?
Abused your bed? does disobedience urge ye?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: That is all one, it is my will

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: It is a most wicked one,
A most absurd one, and will show a Monster;
I had rather be a Whore, and with less sin,
To your present lust, than Queen to your injustice.
Yours is no love, Faith and Religion fly it,
Nor has no taste of fair affection in it,
Some hellish flame abuses your fair body,
And hellish furies blow it; look behind ye,
Divorce ye from a woman of her beauty,
Of her integrity, her piety?
Her love to you, to all that honours ye,
Her chaste and virtuous love, are these fit causes?
What will you do to me, when I have cloyed ye?
You may find time out in eternity,
Deceit and violence in heavenly Justice,
Life in the grave, and death among the blessed,
Ere stain or brack in her sweet reputation.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: You have fooled enough, be wise now, and a woman,
You have showed a modesty sufficient,
If not too much for Court.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: You have showed an impudence,
A more experienced bawd would blush and shake at;
You will make my kindred mighty.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Prithee hear me.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I do Sir, and I count it a great offer.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Any of thine.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: It is like enough you may clap honour on them,
But how it will sit, and how men will adore it,
Is still the question. I will tell you what they will say Sir,
What the report will be, and it will be true too,
And it must needs be comfort to your Master,
These are the issues of her impudence:
I will tell your Grace, so dear I hold the Queen,
So dear that honour that she nursed me up in,
I would first take to me, for my lust, a Moore,
One of your Galley-slaves, that cold and hunger,
Decrepit misery, had made a mock-man,
Than be your Queen.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You are bravely resolute.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I had rather be a Leper, and be shunned,
And die by pieces, rot into my grave,
Leaving no memory behind to know me,
Than be a high Whore to eternity.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You have another Gamester I perceive by ye,
You durst not slight me else.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: I will find him out,
Though he lie next thy heart hid, I will discover him,
And ye proud peat, I will make you curse your insolence.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Tongue of an Angel, and the truth of Heaven,
How am I blessed?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Podramo go in haste
To my Sisters Gentlewoman, you know her well,
And bid her send her Mistress presently
The lesser Cabinet she keeps her Letters in,
And such like toys, and bring it to me Instantly. Away.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: I am gone.

body.stage: Enter the Queen with two Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sora.
sp.l: The Queen.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Let us quit the place, she may grow jealous.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So suddenly departed, what is the reason?
Does my approach displease his Grace? are my eyes
So hateful to him? or my conversation
Infected, that he flies me? fair Evanthe,
Are you there? then I see his shame.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: It is true Madam,
It has pleased his Goodness to be pleasant with me,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is strange to find thy modesty in this place,
Does the King offer fair? does thy face take him?
Never blush Evanthe, it is a very sweet one,
Does he rain gold, and precious promises
Into thy lap? will he advance thy fortunes?
Shalt thou be mighty wench?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Never mock Madam;
It is rather on your part to be lamented,
At least revenged, I can be mighty Lady,
And glorious too, glorious and great, as you are.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He will marry thee.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Who would not be a Queen, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is true Evanthe, it is a brave ambition,
A golden dream, that may delude a good mind,
What shall become of me?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: You must learn to pray,
Your age and honour will become a Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Wilt thou remember me?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: She weeps. Sweet Lady
Upon my knees I ask your sacred pardon,
For my rude boldness; and know, my sweet Mistress,
If ever there were ambition in Evanthe,
It was and is to do you faithful duties;
It is true I have been tempted by the King,
And with no few and potent charms, to wrong ye,
To violate the chaste joys of your bed;
And those not taking hold, to usurp your state,
But she that has been bred up under ye,
And daily fed upon your virtuous precepts,
Still growing strong by example of your goodness,
Having no errant motion from obedience,
Flies from these vanities, as mere illusions;
And armed with honesty, defies all promises.
In token of this truth, I lay my life down
Under your sacred foot, to do you service.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Rise my true friend, thou virtuous, bud of beauty,
Thou Virgins honour, sweetly blow and flourish,
And that rude nipping wind, that seeks to blast thee,
Or taint thy root, be cursed to all posterity;
To my protection from this hour I take ye,
Yes, and the King shall know --

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Give his heat way, Madam,
And it will go out again, he may forget all.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What have we to do with the times? we cannot cure them;
Let them go on, when they are swollen with surfeits
They will burst and stink, then all the world shall smell them

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: A man may live a bawd, and be an honest man.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Yes, and a wise man too, it is a virtuous calling.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: To his own wife especially, or to his sister,
The nearer to his own blood, still the honester;
There want such honest men, would we had more of them .

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: To be a villain is no such rude matter.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: No, if he be a neat one, and a perfect,
Art makes all excellent, what is it Gentlemen.
In a good cause to kill a dozen coxcombs?
That blunt rude fellows call good Patriots?
Nothing, nor never looked after.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: It is even as much, as easy too, as honest, and as clear,
To ravish Matrons, and deflower coy wenches,
But here they are so willing, it is a complement.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: To pull down Churches with pretension,
To build them fairer, may be done with honour,
And all this time believe no God.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I think so, it is faith enough if they name him in their angers,
Or on their rotten Tombs engrave an Angel;
Well, brave Alphonso, how happy had we been,
If thou hadst rained?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Would I had his disease,
Tied like a Leprosy to my posterity,
So he were right again.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What is his Melody?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Nothing but sad and silent melancholy,
Laden with griefs and thoughts, no man knows why neither;
The good brandino Father to the Princess,
Used all the art and industry that might be,
To free Alphonso from this dull calamity,
And seat him in his rule, he was his eldest
And noblest too, had not fair nature stopped in him,
For which cause this was chosen to inherit,
Frederick the younger.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Does he use his brother
With that respect and honour that befits him?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: He is kept privately, as they pretend,
To give more ease and comfort to his sickness;
But he has honest servants, the grave Rugio,
And Fryer Marco, that weight upon his Person,
And in a Monastery he lives.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: It is full of sadness,
To see him when he comes to his fathers Tomb,
As once a day that is his Pilgrimage,
Whilst in devotion the Quire sings an Anthem:
How piously he kneels, and like a Virgin
That some cross fate had cozened of her Love,
Weeps till the stubborn Marble sweats with pity,
And to his groans the whole Quire bears a Chorus.
So do I too.

body.stage: Enter Frederick, Sorano with the Cabinet.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: The King with his contrivers,
This is no place for us.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: This is a Jewel,
Lay it aside, what Paper is that?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: A Letter,
But it is a woman's, Sir, I know by the hand,
And the false orthography, they write old Saxon.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: May be her ghostly mothers, that instructs her.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: No,it is a cozens, and came up with a great Cake.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: Sora.
sp.l: A pair of Gloves the Duchess gave her,
For so the outside says.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: That other Paper?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: A charm for the tooth-ach, here is nothing but Saints and Crosses.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Look in that box, methinks that should hold secrets,

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: It is paint and curls of hair, she begins to exercise.
A glass of water too, I would fain taste it,
But I am wickedly afraid it will silence me,
Never a Conduit Pipe to convey this water.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: These are all Rings, deaths heads, and such memento.
Her Grandmother, and worm-eaten Aunts left to her,
To tell her what her beauty must arrive at.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: That, that.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: They are written Songs Sir, to provoke young Ladies;
Lord, here is a prayer book, how these agree?
Here is a strange Union.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Ever by a surfeit you have a julep set to cool the Patient.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Those, those.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: They are Verses to the blessed Evanthe.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Those may discover,
Read them out Sorano.
To the blessed Evanthe,
Let those complain, that feels Loves cruelty,
And in sad Legends write their woes,
With Roses gently he has corrected me;
My war is without rage or blows;
My Mistress eyes shine fair on my desires,
And hope springs up inflamed with her new fires.
No more an Exile will I dwell,
With folded arms, and sighs all day,
Reckoning the torments of my hell,
And flinging my sweet joys away;
I am called home again to quiet peace,
My Mistress smiles, and all my sorrows cease.
Yet what is living in her eyes?
Or being blessed with her sweet tongue,
If these no other joys imply?
A golden Give, a pleasing wrong:
To be your own but one poor Month, I would give
My youth, my fortune, and then leave to live.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: This is my rival, that I knew the hand now.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: I know it, I have seen it, it is Valerio's,
That hopeful Gentleman's that was brought up with ye,
And by your charge nourished and fed
At the same Table, with the same allowance.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And all this courtesy to ruin me?
Cross my desires? had better have fed humblier,
And stood at greater distance from my fury:
Go for him quickly, find him instantly,
Whilst my impatient heart swells high with choler;
Better have loved despair, and safer kissed her.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Thou old weak fool, dost thou know to what end,
To what betraying end he got this Casket?
Durst thou deliver him without my Ring?
Or a command from mine own mouth? that Cabinet
That holds my heart, you inconsiderate ass,
Thou brainless Idiot.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I saw you go with him,
At their first word commit your person to him,
And made no scruple; he is your brothers Gentleman,
And for anything I know, an honest man;
And might not I upon the same security deliver him a box?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: A Bottle-head.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You shall have cause to chafe, as I will handle it.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: I had rather thou hadst delivered me to Pirates,
Betrayed me to incurable diseases,
Hung up my Picture in a Market place,
And sold me to wild bawds.

sp.speaker: Cassan.
sp.l: As I take it Madam,
Your Maidenhead lies not in that Cabinet,
You have a Closet, and you keep the key too,
Why are you vexed thus?

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: I could curse thee wickedly,
And wish thee more deformed than age can make thee,
Perpetual hunger, and no teeth to satisfy it,
Weight on thee still, nor sleep be found to ease it:
Those hands that gave the Casket, may the Palsy
Forever make unuseful, even to feed thee;
Long winters, that thy bones may turn to Icicles
No Hell can thaw again, inhabit by thee.
Is thy care like thy body, all on crookedness?
How scurvily thou criest now? like a drunkard,
I will have as pure tears from a dirty spout:
Do, swear thou didst this ignorantly, swear it,
Swear and be damned, thou half witch.

sp.speaker: Cassan.
sp.l: These are fine words, well Madam, Madam.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: It is not well thou mummy,
It is impudently, basely done, thou dirty --

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Has your young sanctity done railing, Madam,
Against your innocent Squire? do you see this Sonnet?
This loving Script? do you know from whence it came too?

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: I do, and dare avouch it pure and honest.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You have private Visitants, my noble Lady,
That in sweet numbers court your goodly vertues,
And to the height of adoration.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Well Sir,
There is neither Heresy nor Treason in it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: A Prince may beg at the door; whilst these feast with ye;
A favour or a grace, from such as I am.
Course, common things. You are welcome; pray come near, Sir,
Do you know this paper?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am betrayed; I do Sir,
It is mine, my hand and heart, if I die for her,
I am thy Martyr, Love, and time shall honour me.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: You saucy Sir, that came in my Ladies name,
For her guilt Cabinet, you cheating Sir too,
You scurvy Usher, with as scurvy legs,
And a worse face, thou poor base hanging holder,
How durst thou come to me with a lie in thy mouth?
An impudent lie?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: Hollow, good Jill, you hobble.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: A stinking lie, more stinking than the teller,
To play the pilfering knave, there have been rascals
Brought up to fetch and carry like your Worship
That have been hanged for less, whipped there are daily
And if the Law will do me right --

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: What then old Maggot?

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Thy mother was carted younger; I will have thy hide,
Thy mangy hide, embroidered with a dog-whip,
As it is now with potent Pox, and thicker.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace, good antiquity, I will have your bones else
Ground into Gunpowder to shoot at Cats with;
One word more, and I will blanch thee like an Almond,
There is no such cure for the she-falling- sickness,
As the powder of a dried bawds skin, be silent,
You are very prodigal of your service here, Sir,
Of your life more it seems.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I repent neither,
Because Your Grace shall understand it comes
From the best part of love, my pure affection,
And kindled with chaste flame, I will not fly from it,
If it be error to desire to marry,
And marry her that sanctity would dote on,
I have done amiss; if it be a Treason
To graft my soul to virtue, and to grow there,
To love the tree that bears such happiness;
Conceive me, Sir, this fruit was never forbidden;
Nay, to desire to taste too, I am Traitor;
Had you but plants enough of this blessed Tree, Sir,
Set round about your Court to beautify it,
Deaths twice so many, to dismay the approachers,
The ground would scarce yield graves to noble Lovers.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It is well maintained, you wish and pray to fortune,
Here in your Sonnet, and she has heard your prayers,
So much you dote upon your own undoing,
But one Month to enjoy her as your wife,
Though at the expiring of that time you die for it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I could wish many, many ages Sir,
To grow as old as time in her embraces,
If heaven would grant it, and you smile upon it;
But if my choice were two hours, and then perish,
I would not pull my heart back.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You have your wish,
Tomorrow I will see you nobly married,
Your Month take out in all content and pleasure;
The first day of the following Month you die for it;
Kneel not, not all your prayers can divert me;
Now mark your sentence, mark it scornful Lady,
If when Valerio is dead, within twelve hours,
For that is your latest time, you find not out
Another husband on the same condition
To marry you again, you die yourself too.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Now you are merciful, I thank your Grace.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: If when you are married, you but seek to scape
Out of the Kingdom, you, or she, or both,
Or to infect men's minds with hot commotions,
You die both instantly; will you love me now Lady?
My tale will now be heard, but now I scorn ye.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Is our fair love, our honest, our entire,
Come to this hazard?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is a noble one, and I am much in love with malice for it,
Envy could not have studied me away ,
Nor fortune pointed out a path to honour,
Straighter and nobler, if she had her eyes:
When I have once enjoyed my sweet Evanthe,
And blessed my youth with her most dear Embraces,
I have done my journey here, my day is out,
All that the world has else is foolery,
Labour, and loss of time, what should I live for?
Think but man's life a month, and we are happy.
I would not have my joys grow old for anything;
A paradise, as thou art my Evanthe,
Is only made to wonder at a little,
Enough for human eyes, and then to wander from.
Come do not weep, sweet, you dishonour me,
Your tears and griefs but question my ability,
Whether I dare die: Do you love entirely?

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: You know I do.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Then grudge not my felicity.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: I will to the Queen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do anything that is honest,
But if you sue to him in death, I hate you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Was there ever heard of such a marriage?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Marriage and hanging go by destiny,
It is the old proverb, now they come together.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: But a month married, then to lose his life for it?
I would have a long month sure that pays the Soldiers,

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Or get all the Almanacs burnt, that were a rare trick,
And have no month remembered. How now Tony?
Whose water are you casting?

sp.speaker: Tony.
sp.l: A sick Gentlemans,
Is very sick, much troubled with the stone,
He should not live above a month by his Urine,
About Saint Davids day it will go hard with him,
He will then be troubled with a pain in his neck too.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: A pestilent fool; when wilt thou marry Tony?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: When I mean to be hanged, and it is the surer contract.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What think you of this marriage of Valerios?

sp.speaker: Tony.
sp.p: They have given him a hot custard, and mean to burn his mouth with it; had I known he had been given to die honourably, I would have helped him to a wench, a rare one, should have killed him in three weeks, and saved the sentence.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: There be them would have spared ten days of that too.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: It may be so, you have women of all vertues;
There be some Guns that I could bring him too,
Some Mortar-pieces that are placed in the Suburbs,
Would tear him into quartets in two hours;
There be also of the race of the old Cockatrices,
That would dispatch him with once looking on him.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: What Month wouldst thou choose Tony, if thou hadst the like fortune?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.p: I would choose a mulled Sack month, to comfort my belly, for sure my back would ache for it, and at the months end I would be most dismally drunk, and scorn the gallows.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: I would choose March, for I would come in like a Lion.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: But you would go out like a Lamb, when you went to hanging.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I would take April, take the sweet of the year,
And kiss my wench upon the tender flowerets,
Tumble on every Green, and as the birds sung,
Embrace and melt away my soul in pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: You would go aMaying gaily to the gallows.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Prithee tell us some news.

sp.speaker: Tony.
sp.l: I will tell ye all I know,
You may be honest and poor fools, as I am,
And blow your fingers ends.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: That is no news fool.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: You may be knaves then, when you please, stark knaves,
And build fair houses, but your heirs shall have none of them.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: These are undoubted.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Truth is not worth the hearing,
I will tell you news then, There was a drunken Sailor,
That got a Mermaid with child as she went amilking ,
And now she sues him in the bawdy Court for it,
The infant Monster is brought up in fish-street.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Aye , this is something.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: I will tell you more, There was a fish taken,
A monstrous fish, with a sword by his side, a long sword,
A pike in his neck, and a gun in his nose, a huge gun,
And letters of Mart in his mouth, from the Duke of Florence.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: This is a monstrous lie.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: I do confess it;
Do you think I would tell you truths, that dare not hear them?
You are honest things, we Courtiers scorn to converse with.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: A plaguey fool, but let us consider Gentlemen.
Why the Queen strives not to oppose this sentence,
The Kingdoms honour suffers in this cruelty.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: No doubt the Queen, though she be virtuous,
Winks at the marriage, for by that only means
The Kings flame lessens to the youthful Lady,
If not goes out, within this month, I doubt not,
She hopes to rock asleep his anger also;
Shall we go see the preparation?
It is time, for strangers come to view the wonder.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Come, let us away, send my friends happier weddings.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: You shall be merry, come,I will have it so,
Can there be any nature so innoble?
Or anger so inhumane to pursue this?

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: I fear there is.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: Your fears are poor and foolish,
Though he be hasty, and his anger death,
His will like torrents, not to be resisted,
Yet Law and Justice go along to guide him;
And what Law or what Justice can he find
To justify his will? what Act or Statute,
By Human or Divine establishment,
Left to direct us, that makes marriage death?
Honest fair wedlock? it was given for increase,
For preservation of mankind I take it;
He must be more than man then, that dare break it;
Come dress ye handsomely, you shall have my Jewels,
And put a face on that contemns base fortune,
It will make him more insult to see you fearful,
Outlook his anger.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: O my Valerio!
Be witness my pure mind, it is thee I grieve for.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: But show it not, I would so crucify him
With an innocent neglect of what he can do,
A brave strong pious scorn, that I would shake him;
Put all the wanton Cupids in thine eyes,
And all the graces on that nature gave thee,
Make up thy beauty to that height of excellence,
I will help thee, and forgive thee, as if Venus
Were now again to catch the God of War,
In his most rugged anger, when thou hast him
(As it is impossible he should resist thee)
And kneeling at thy conquering feet for mercy,
Then show thy virtue, then again despise him
And all his power, then with a look of honour,
Mingled with noble chastity, strike him dead.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Good Madam dress me,
You arm me bravely.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: Make him know his cruelty
Begins with him first, he must suffer for it,
And that thy sentence is so welcome to thee,
And to thy noble Lord, You long to meet it.
Stamp such a deep impression of thy beauty
Into his soul, and of thy worthiness,
That when Valerio and Evanthe sleep
In one rich earth, hung round about with blessings,
He may run mad, and curse his act; be lusty,
I will teach thee how to die too, if thou fearest it.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I thank your Grace, you have prepared me strongly,
And my weak mind.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: Death is unwelcome never,
Unless it be to tortured minds and sick souls,
That make their own Hells;it is such a benefit
When it comes crowned with honour, shows so sweet too,
Though they paint it ugly, that is but to restrain us,
For every living thing would love it else,
Fly boldly to their peace, ere nature called them;
The rest we have from labour, and from trouble,
Is some incitement, every thing alike,
The poor slave that lies private has his liberty,
As amply as his Master, in that Tomb,
The earth as light upon him, and the flowers
That grow about him, smell as sweet, and flourish,
But when we love with honour to our ends,
When memory and vertues are our mourners,
What pleasure is there? they are infinite Evanthe;
Only, my virtuous wench, we want our senses,
That benefit we are barred, it would make us proud else,
And lazy to look up to happier life,
The blessings of the people would so swell us.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Good Madam dress me, you have dressed my soul,
The merriest Bride I will be for all this misery,
The proudest to some eyes too.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: It will do better, come shrink no more.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I am too confident.

sp.speaker: Sora.
sp.l: You are too remiss and wanton in your angers,
You mold things handsomely, and then neglect them;
A powerful Prince should be constant to his power still,
And hold up what he builds, then people fear him;
When he lets loose his hand, it shows a weakness,
And men examine or contemn his greatness;
A scorn of this high kind should have called up
A revenge equal, not a pity in you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She is thy sister.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: If she were my mother,
Whilst I conceive she has you wronged, I hate her,
And shake her nearness off; I study, Sir,
To satisfy your angers that are just,
Before your pleasures.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I have done that already,
I fear has pulled too many curses on me.

sp.speaker: Sora.
sp.l: Curses or envies, on Valerio's head,
Would you take my counsel, Sir, they should all light,
And with the weight, not only crack his scull,
But his fair credit; the exquisite vexation
I have devised, so please you give way in it,
And let it work, shall more afflict his soul,
And trench upon that honour that he brags of,
Then fear of death in all the frights he carries;
If you sit down here they will both abuse ye,
Laugh at your poor relenting power, and scorn ye;
What satisfaction can their deaths bring to you,
That are prepared and proud to die, and willingly,
And at their ends will thank you for that honour?
How are you nearer the desire you aim at?
Or if it be revenge your anger covets,
How can their single deaths give you content, Sir?
Petty revenges end in blood, sleight angers,
A Princes rage should find out new diseases,
Death were a pleasure too, to pay proud fools with.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What should I do?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Add but your power unto me,
Make me but strong by your protection,
And you shall see what joy, and what delight,
What infinite pleasure this poor mouth shall yield him,
I will make him wish he were dead on his marriage day,
Or bedridden with old age, I will make him curse,
And cry and curse, give me but power.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You have it,
Here take my Ring, I am content he pay for it.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: It shall be now revenge, as I will handle it,
He shall live after this to beg his life too,
Twenty to one by this thread, as I will weave it,
Evanthe shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Take all authority, and be most happy.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Good Sir, no more pity.

body.stage: Enter Tony, three Citizens, and three Wives.

sp.speaker: 1.Wife.
sp.l: Good Master Tony, put me in.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Where do you dwell?

sp.speaker: 1.Wife.
sp.l: Forsooth, at the sign of the great shoulder of Mutton,

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: A hungry man would hunt your house out instantly, Keep the dogs from your door; Is this Lettuce Ruff your husband? a fine sharp sallet to your sign.

sp.speaker: 2.Wife.
sp.l: Will you put me in too?

sp.speaker: 3.Wife
sp.l: And me, good Master Tony.

sp.speaker: Tony.
sp.l: Put ye all in? you had best come twenty more; you
Think it is easy, a trick of legerdemain, to put ye all in,
It would pose a fellow that had twice my body,
Though it were all made into chines and fillets.

sp.speaker: 2.W.
sp.l: Put us into the wedding, Sir, we would fain see that.

sp.speaker: 1.W.
sp.l: And the brave Masque too.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: You two are pretty women, are you their husbands?

sp.speaker: 2 Citz.
sp.l: Yes, for want of better.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: I think so too, you would not be so mad else
To turn them loose to a company of young Courtiers,
That swarm like Bees in May, when they see young wenches;
You must not squeak.

sp.speaker: 3.W.
sp.l: No Sir, we are better tutored.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Nor if a young Lord offer you the courtesy --

sp.speaker: 2.W.
sp.l: We know what it is, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Nor you must not grumble,
If you be thrust up hard, we thrust most furiously.

sp.speaker: 1.W.
sp.l: We know the worst.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Get you two in then quietly,
And shift for yourselves; we must have no old women,
They are out of use, unless they have petitions,
Besides they cough so loud they drown the Music,
You would go in too, but there is no place for ye,
I am sorry for it, go and forget your wives,
Or pray they may be able to suffer patiently.
You may have Heirs may prove wise Aldermen,
Go, or I will call the Guard.

sp.speaker: 3 Citz.
sp.l: We will get in, we will venture broken pates else.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: It is impossible,
You are too securely armed; how they flock hither,
And with what joy the women run by heaps
To see this Marriage? they tickle to think of it,
They hope for every month a husband too;
Still how they run, and how the wittols follow them,
The weak things that are worn between the legs,
That brushing, dressing, nor new naps can mend,
How they post to see their own confusion?
This is a merry world.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Look to the door sirrah,
Thou art a fool, and mayst do mischief lawfully.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Give me your hand, you are my brother Fool,
You may both make the Law, and mar it presently.
Do you love a wench?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Who does not fool?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Not I, unless you will give me a longer lease to marry her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What are all these that come, what business have they?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Some come to gape, those are my fellow fools
Some to get home their wives, those be their own fools;
Some to rejoice with thee, those be the times fools;
And some I fear to curse thee, those are poor fools.
sp.stage: Enter Cassandra, an old Lady passing over.
sp.l: A set people calls them honest.Look,look King, look,
A weather-beaten Lady new careened.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: An old one.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: The glasses of her eyes are new rubbed over,
And the worm-eaten records in her face are daubed up neatly;
She lays her breasts out too, like to poached eggs
That had the yolks sucked out; they get new heads also,
New teeth, new tongues, for the old are all worn-out,
And as it is hoped, new tails.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: For old Courtiers,
The young ones are too stirring for their travels.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Go leave your knavery, and help to keep the door well,
I will have no such press.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Lay thy hand on thy heart King.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I will have ye whipped.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: The Fool and thou are parted.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Sorano work, and free me from this spell,
Betwixt love and scorn there is nothing felt but hell.

body.stage: Enter Valerio, Camillo, Cleanthes, Menallo, and Servants.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Tie on my Scarf, you are so long about me,
Good my Lords help, give me my other Cloak,
That Hat and Feather, Lord what a Taylor is this,
To make me up thus straight, one sigh would burst me,
I have not room to breath, come button, button,
Button, apace.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I am glad to see you merry Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It would make you merry had you such a wife,
And such an age to enjoy her in.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: An age Sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A month is an age to him that is contented,
What should I seek for more? give me my sword.
Ha my good Lords, that every one of you now
Had but a Lady of that youth and beauty
To bless yourselves this night with, would ye not?
Pray ye speak uprightly.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: We confess ye happy,
And we could well wish such another Banquet,
But on that price my Lord --

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It were nothing else,
No man can ever come to aim at Heaven,
But by the knowledge of a Hell. These shoes are heavy,
And if I should be called to dance they will clog me,
Get me some pumps; I will tell ye brave Camillo,
And you dear friends, the King has honoured me,
Out of his gracious favour has much honoured me,
To limit me my time, for who would live long?
Who would be old? it is such a weariness,
Such a disease, that hangs like lead upon us
As it increases, so vexations,
Griefs of the mind, pains of the feeble body,
Rheums, coughs, catarrhs, we are but our living coffins;
Beside, the fair souls old too, it grows covetous,
Which shows all honour is departed from us,
And we are earth again.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You make fair use Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I would not live to learn to lie Cleanthes
For all the world, old men are prone to that too;
Thou that hast been a Soldier, Menallo
A noble Soldier, and defied all danger,
Adopted thy brave arm the heir to victory,
Wouldest thou live so long till thy strength forsook thee?
Till thou grewest only a long tedious story
Of what thou hadst been? till thy sword hang by,
And lazy Spiders filled the hilt with cobwebs?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: No sure, I would not.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is not fit ye should,
To die a young man is to be an Angel,
Our great good parts, put wings to our souls:
We will have a rouse before we go to bed friends,
Pray ye tell me, is it a handsome Mask we have?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: We understand so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And the young gent. dance?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: They do Sir, and some dance well.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: They must before the Ladies,
We will have a rouse before we go to bed friends,
A lusty one, it will make my blood dance too.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Ten if you please.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And we will be wondrous merry,
They stay sure, come, I hear the Music forward,
You shall have all Gloves presently.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: We attend Sir, but first we must look to the
Doors.
The King has charged us.

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.l: What a noise do you keep there, call my fellows
At the Guard; you must cease now until the King be
Entered, he is gone to the Temple now.

sp.speaker: 2 Serv.
sp.l: Look to that back door, and keep it fast,
They swarm like Bees about it,

body.stage: Enter Camillo, Cleanthes, Menallo, Tony following, and Fool following.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Keep back those Citizens, and let their wives in,
Their handsome wives.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: They have crowded me to Vergis,
I sweat like a Butter-box.

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.l: Stand further off there.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Take the women aside, and talk with them in private,
Give them that they came for.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: The whole Court cannot do it;
Besides, the next Mask if we use them so,
They will come by millions to expect our largess;
We have broke a hundred heads.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Are they so tender?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: But it was behind, before they have all murrions.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Let in those Ladies, make them room for shame there.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: They are no Ladies, there is one bald before them,
A gent. bald, they are curtailed queans in hired clothes,
They come out of Spaine I think, they are very sultry.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Keep them in breath for an Ambassador.
Methinks my nose shakes at their memories,
What bouncing is that?
I am one of the Music Sir.
I have sweet-meats for the banquet.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Let them in.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: They lie my Lord, they come to seek their wives,
Two broken Citizens.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Break them more, they are but brusled yet.
Bold Rascals, offer to disturb your wives.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Lock the doors fast, the Music, hark, the King comes.

body.stage: The King, Queen, Valerio, Evanthe, Ladies, Attendants, Camillo, Cleanthes, Sorano, Menallo.
Cupid descends, the Graces sitting by him, Cupid being bound the Graces unbind him, he speaks.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Unbind me, my delight, this night is mine,
Now let me look upon what Stars here shine,
Let me behold the beauties, then clap high
My coloured wings, proud of my Deity;
I am satisfied, bind me again, and fast,
My angry Bow will make too great a waste
Of beauty else, now call my Maskers in,
Call with a Song, and let the sports begin;
Call all my servants the effects of love,
And to a measure let them nobly move.
Come you servants of proud love,
Come away:
Fairly, nobly, gently move,
Too long, too long you make us stay;
Fancy, Desire, Delight, Hope, Fear,
Distrust and Jealousy, be you too here;
Consuming Care, and raging Ire,
And Poverty in poor attire,
March fairly in, and last Despair;
Now full Music strike the Air.

body.stage: Enter the Maskers, Fancy, Desire, Delight, Hope, Fear, Distrust, Jealousy, Care, Ire, Despair, they dance, after which Cupid speaks.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Away, I have done, the day begins to light,
Lovers, you know your fate, good night, good night.

body.stage: Cupid and the Graces ascend in the Chariot.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come to the Banquet, when that is ended Sir,
I will see you a bed, and so good night; be merry,
You have a sweet bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I thank your Grace,
And ever shall be bound unto your nobleness.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I pray I may deserve your thanks, set forward.

body.stage: Enter divers Monks, Alphonso going to the Tomb, Rugio and Frier Marco discover the Tomb and a Chair.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The night grows on, lead softly to the Tomb,
And sing not till I bid ye; let the Music
Play gently as he passes.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: O fair picture,
That wert the living hope of all our honours;
How are we banished from the joy we dreamt of?
Will he never speak more?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is full three months Lord Rugio,
Since any articulate sound came from his tongue,
Set him down gently.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: What should the reason be Sir?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: As it is in nature with those loving Husbands,
That sympathize their wives pains, and their throws
When they are breeding, and it is usual too,
We have it by experience so in him Sir,
In this most noble spirit that now suffers;
For when his honoured Father good Brandino
Fell sick, he felt the griefs, and laboured with them,
His sits and his disease he still inherited,
Grew the same thing, and had not nature checked him,
Strength, and ability, he had died that hour too.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: Emblem of noble love!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That very minute
His fathers breath forsook him, that same instant,
A rare example of his piety,
And love paternal, the Organ of his tongue
Was never heard to sound again; so near death
He seeks to wait upon his worthy Father,
But that we force his meat, he were one body.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: He points to the Tomb.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That is the place he honours,
A house I fear he will not be long out of.
He will to the Tomb, good my Lord lend your hand;
Now sing the Funeral Song, and let him kneel,
For then he is pleased.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: Heaven lend thy powerful hand,
And ease this Prince.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He will pass back again.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: They drink abundantly, I am hot with wine too,
Lustily warm, I will steal now to my happiness,
It is midnight, and the silent hour invites me,
But she is up still, and attends the Queen;
Thou dew of wine and sleep hang on their eye-lids,
Steep their dull senses in the healths they drink,
That I may quickly find my loved Evanthe.
The King is merry too, and drank unto me,
Sign of fair peace, O this night is blessedness!
If I had forty heads I would give all for it.
Is not the end of our ambitions,
Of all our human studies, and our travels,
Of our desires, the obtaining of our wishes?
Certain it is, and there man makes his Centre.
I have obtained Enanthe, I have married her,
Can any fortune keep me from enjoying her?
I have my wish, what is left me to accuse now?
I am friends with all the world, but thy base malice;
Go glory in thy mischiefs thou proud man,
And cry it to the world thou hast ruined virtue;
How I contemn thee and thy petty malice,
And with what scorn I look down on thy practice.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: You will sing me a new Song anon Ualerio,
And wish these hot words --

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I despise thee fellow,
Thy threats, or flatteries, all I fling behind me;
I have my end, I have thy noble Sister,
A name too worthy of thy blood; I have married her,
And will enjoy her too.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: It is very likely.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And that short month I have to bless me with her
I will make an age,I will reckon each embrace
A year of pleasure, and each night a Jubilee,
Every quick kiss a Spring; and when I mean
To lose myself in all delightfulness,
Twenty sweet Summers I will tie together
In spite of thee, and thy malignant Master:
I will die old in love, though young in pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: But that I hate thee deadly, I could pity thee,
Thou art the poorest miserable thing
This day on earth;I will tell thee why Valerio,
All thou esteemest, and buildest upon for happiness,
For joy, for pleasure, for delight is past thee,
And like a wanton dream already vanished.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Is my love false?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: No, she is constant to thee,
Constant to all thy misery she shall be,
And curse thee too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Is my strong body weakened,
Charmed, or abused with subtle drink? speak villain.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Neither, I dare speak, thou art still as lusty
As when thou lovedest her first, as strong and hopeful,
The month thou hast given thee is a month of misery,
And where thou thinkest each hour shall yield a pleasure
Look for a killing pain, for thou shalt find it
Before thou diest, each minute shall prepare it,
And ring so many knells to sad afflictions;
The King has given thee a long month to die in,
And miserably die.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Undo thy Riddle,
I am prepared what ever fate shall follow.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Dost thou see this Ring?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know it too.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Then mark me,
By virtue of this Ring this I pronounce to thee,
It is the Kings will.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Let me know it suddenly.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: If thou dost offer to touch Evanthes body
Beyond a kiss, though thou art married to her,
And lawfully as thou thinkest mayst enjoy her,
That minute she shall die.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O Devil --

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: If thou discover this command unto her,
Or to a friend that shall importune thee,
And why thou abstainest, and from whose will, ye all perish,
Upon the self-same forfeit are ye fitted Sir,
Now if ye love her, ye may preserve her life still,
If not, you know the worst, how falls your month out?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This tyranny could never be invented
But in the school of Hell, earth is too innocent;
Not to enjoy her when she is my wife?
When she is willing too?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: She is most willing,
And will run mad to miss; but if you hit her,
Be sure you bit her home, and kill her with it;
There are such women that will die with pleasure:
The Axe will follow else, that will not fail
To fetch her Maiden-head, and dispatch her quickly;
Then shall the world know you are the cause of Murther,
And as it is requisite your life shall pay for it .

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Thou dost but jest, thou canst not be so monstrous
As thou proclaimest thy thyself; thou art her Brother,
and there must be a feeling heart within thee
Of her afflictions; wert thou a stranger to us,
And bred amongst wild rocks, thy nature wild too,
Affection in thee as thy breeding, cold,
And unrelenting as the rocks that nourished thee,
Yet thou must shake to tell me this; they tremble
When the rude sea threatens divorce amongst them,
They that are senseless things shake at a tempest;
Thou art a man --

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Be thou too then, it will try thee,
And patience now will best become thy nobleness.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Invent some other torment to afflict me,
All, if thou please, put all afflictions on me,
Study thy brains out for them, so this be none
I care not of what nature, nor what cruelty,
Nor of what length.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: This is enough to vex ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The tale of Tantalus is now proved true,
And from me shall be registered Authentic;
To have my joys within my arms, and lawful,
Mine own delights, yet dare not touch.
Even as thou hatest me Brother, let no young man know this,
As thou shalt hope for peace when thou most needest it,
Peace in thy soul, desire the King to kill me,
Make me a traitor, anything, I will yield to it,
And give thee cause so I may die immediately;
Lock me in Prison where no Sun may see me,
In walls so thick no hope may ere come at me;
Keep me from meat, and drink, and sleep,I will bless thee;
Give me some damned potion to deliver me,
That I may never know self again , forget
My Country kindred, name and fortune; last,
That my chaste love may never appear before me,
This were some comfort.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: All I have I have brought ye,
And much may it do ye with it my dear Brother,
See ye observe it well; you will find about ye
Many eyes set, that shall overlook your actions,
If you transgress ye know, and so I leave ye,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Heaven be not angry, and I have some hope yet,
And when you please, and how allay my miseries.
To whom I kneel be merciful unto me,
Look on my harmless youth Angels of pity,
And from my bleeding heart wipe off my sorrows,
The power, the pride, the malice and injustice
Of cruel men are bent against mine innocence.
You that control the mighty wills of Princes,
And bow their stubborn arms, look on my weakness,
And when you please, and how, allay my miseries.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Hast thou been with him?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Yes, and given him that Sir
Will make him curse his Birth; I told ye which way,
Did you but see him Sir, but look upon him,
With what a troubled and dejected nature
He walks now in a mist, with what a silence,
As if he were the shroud he wrapped himself in,
And no more of Valerio but his shadow,
He seeks obscurity to hide his thoughts in,
You would wonder and admire for all you know it,
His jollity is down, valed to the ground Sir,
And his high hopes of full delights and pleasures
Are turned tormentors to him, strong diseases.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: But is there hope of her?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: It must fall necessary
She must dislike him, quarrel with his person,
For women once deluded are next Devils,
And in the height of that opinion Sir,
You shall put on again, and she must meet ye,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I am glad of this.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: I will tell ye all the circumstance
Within this hour, but sure I heard your Grace
Today as I attended, make some stops,
Some broken speeches, and some sighs between,
And then your Brothers name I heard distinctly,
And some sad wishes after.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ye are in the right Sir,
I would he were as sad as I could wish him,
Sad as the earth.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Would ye have it so?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou hearest me,
Though he be sick with small hope of recovery,
That hope still lives, and men's eyes live upon it,
And in their eyes their wishes; my Sorano,
Were he but cold once in the tomb he dotes on,
As it is the fittest place for melancholy,
My Court should be another Paradise,
And flow with all delights.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Go to your pleasures, let me alone with this,
Hope shall not trouble ye, nor he three days.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I shall be bound unto thee.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: I will do it neatly too, no doubt shall catch me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Be gone, they are going to bed, I will bid good night to them.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: And mark the man, you will scarce know it is Valerio.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Cheer up my noble Lord, the minutes come;
You shall enjoy the abstract of all sweetness,
We did you wrong you need no wine to warm ye,
Desire shoots through your eyes like sudden wildfires.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Beshrew me Lords, the wine has made me dull,
I am I know not what.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Good pleasure to ye,
Good night and long too, as you find your appetite
You may fall too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I do beseech your Grace,
For which of all my loves and services
Have I deserved this:

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I am not bound to answer ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nor I bound to obey in unjust actions.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Do as you please, you know the penalty,
And as I have a soul it shall be executed;
Nay look not pale, I am not used to fear Sir,
If you respect your Lady, good night to ye

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But for respect to her and to my duty,
That reverent duty that I owe my Sovereign,
Which anger has no power to snatch me from,
The good night should be thine; good night forever ,
The King is wanton Lords, he would needs know of me
How many nick chases I would make tonight.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: My Lord, no doubt you will prove a perfect gamester.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Faith no, I am unacquainted with the pleasure,
Bungle a set I may, how my heart trembles,
And beats my breast as it would break his way out
Good night my noble friends.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Nay we must see you toward your bed my Lord:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good faith it needs not,
It is late, and I shall trouble you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: No, no, till the Bride come Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I beseech you leave me,
You will make me bashful else, I am so foolish,
Besides, I have some few devotions Lords,
And he that can pray with such a book in his arms --

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: We will leave ye then, and a sweet night wait upon ye.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: And a sweet issue of this sweet night crown ye.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: All nights and days be such till you grow old Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I thank ye, it is a curse sufficient for me,
A laboured one too, though you mean a blessing.
What shall I do, I am like a wretched Debtor,
That has a sum to tender on the forfeit
Of all he is worth, yet dare not offer it.
Other men see the Sun, yet I must wink at it;
And though I know it is perfect day, deny it:
My veins are all on fire, and burn like Aetna,
Youth and desire beat larums to my blood,
And add fresh fuel to my warm affections.
I must enjoy her, yet when I consider,
When I collect myself, and weigh her danger,
The Tyrants will, and his power taught to murther,
My tender care controls my blood within me,
And like a cold fit of a peevish Ague
Creeps to my soul, and flings an Ice upon me.
sp.stage: Enter Queen, Evanthe, Ladies, and Fool.
sp.l: That locks all powers of youth up but prevention;
O what a blessedness it were to be old now,
To be unable, bed-rid with diseases,
Or halt on Crutches to meet holy Hymen;
What a rare benefit, but I am cursed
That that speaks other men most freely happy,
And makes all eyes hang on their expectations,
Must prove the bane of me youth, and ability.
She comes to bed, how shall I entertain her?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Nay I come after too, take the fool with ye,
For lightly he is ever one at Weddings.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Evanthe, make ye unready, your Lord stays for ye,
And prithee be merry.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Be very merry, Chicken,
Thy Lord will pipe to thee anon, and make thee dance too.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Will he so, good-man ass.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Yes goody silly,
If you had such a Pipe, that piped so sweetly,
You would dance to death, you have learnt your sinque-a-pace.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Your Grace desires that that is too free in me,
I am merry at the heart.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Thou wilt be anon, the young smug Boy will give thee a sweet cordial.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I am so taken up in all my thoughts,
So possessed Madam with the lawful sweets
I shall this night partake of with my Lord,
So far transported (pardon my immodesty)

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Alas poor wench, how shall I recompense thee?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: That though they must be short, and snatched away too,
Ere they grow ripe, yet I shall far prefer them
Before a tedious pleasure with repentance.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O how my heart aches.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Take off my Jewels Ladies,
And let my Ruff loose, I shall bid good night to ye,
My Lord stays here.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: My wench, I thank thee heartily,
For learning how to use thy few hours handsomely,
They will be years I hope; off with your Gown now,
Lay down the bed there?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Shall I get into it and warm it for thee, a Fools fire is a fine thing,
And I will so buss thee.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: I will have ye whipped ye rascal.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: That will provoke me more, I will talk with thy husband,
He is a wise man I hope.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Good night dear Madam,
Ladies, no further service, I am well,
I do beseech your Grace to give us this leave,
My Lord and I to one another freely,
And privately, may do all other Ceremonies,
Women and Page we will be to one another,
And trouble you no farther.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Art thou a wise man?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I cannot tell thee Tony, ask my neighbours.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: If thou beest so, go lie with me tonight,
The old fool will lie quieter than the young one,
And give thee more sleep, thou wilt look tomorrow else
Worse than the prodigal fool the Ballad speaks of,
That was squeezed through a horn.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I shall take thy counsel.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Why then good night, good night my best Evanthe,
My worthy maid, and as that name shall vanish,
A worthy wife, a long and happy; follow sirrah.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: That shall be my care,
Goodness rest with your Grace.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Be lusty Lord, and take your Lady to ye,
And that power that shall part ye be unhappy.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sweet rest unto ye, to ye all sweet Ladies;
Tony good night.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Shall not the Fool stay with thee?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Come away Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: How the Fool is sought for, sweet Malt is made of easy fire,
A hasty horse will quickly tire, a sudden leaper sticks in the mire,
Phlebotomy and the word lie nigh, take heed of friend I thee require;
This from an Almanac I stole, and learnt this Lesson from a fool.
Good night my Bird.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Good night wise Master Tony;
Will ye to bed my Lord? Come, let me help ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: To bed Evanthe, art thou sleepy?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: No, I shall be worse if you look sad upon me,
Pray ye let us to bed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am not well my love.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I will make ye well, there is no such Physic for ye
As your warm Mistress arms.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Art thou so cunning?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I speak not by experience, pray ye mistake not;
But if you love me --

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: I do love so dearly,
So much above the base bent of desire
I know not how to answer thee.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: To bed then,
There I shall better credit yea; sigh my Lord,
Will ye put a maid to it, to teach ye what to do?
An innocent maid? Are ye so cold a Lover?
Intruth you make me blush, it is midnight too,
And it is no stolen love, but authorised openly,
No sin we covet, pray let me undress ye,
You shall help me; prithee sweet Valerio;
Be not so sad, the King will be more merciful.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: May not I love thy mind?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: And I yours too,
It is a most noble one, adorned with virtue;
But if we love not one another really,
And put our bodies and our minds together,
And so make up the concord of affection,
Our love will prove but a blind superstition:
This is no school to argue in my Lord,
Nor have we time to talk away allowed us,
Pray let us dispatch, if anyone should come
And find us at this distance, what would they think?
Come, kiss me and to bed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That I dare do, and kiss again.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Spare not, they are your own Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But to enjoy thee is to be luxurious,
Too sensual in my love, and too ambitious;
O how I burn! to pluck thee from the stalk,
Where now thou growest a sweet bud and a beauteous,
And bearest the prime and honour of the Garden,
Is but to violate thy spring, and spoil thee.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: To let me blow, and fall alone would anger ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Let us sit together thus, and as we sit
Feed on the sweets of one another's souls,
The happiness of love is contemplation,
The blessedness of love is pure affection,
Where no allay of actual dull desire,
Of pleasure that partakes with wantonness,
Of human fire that burns out as it kindles,
And leaves the body but a poor repentance,
Can ever mix, let us six on that Evanthe,
That is everlasting, the the other casual;
Eternity breeds one, the other Fortune,
Blind as herself, and full of all afflictions.
Shall we love virtuously?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I ever loved so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And only think our love; the rarest pleasure,
And that we most desire, let it be human,
If once enjoyed grows stale, and cloys our appetites;
I would not lessen in my love for anything,
Nor find thee but the same in my short journey,
For my loves safety.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Now I see I am old Sir,
Old and ill-favoured too, poor and despised,
And am not worth your noble Fellowship,
Your fellowship in Love, you would not else
Thus cunningly seek to betray a maid,
A maid that honours you thus piously;
Strive to abuse the pious love she brings ye.
Farewell my Lord, since ye have a better Mistress,
For it must seem so, or ye are no man,
A younger, happier, I shall give her room,
So much I love ye still.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Stay my Evanthe,
Heaven bear me witness, thou art all I love,
All I desire, and now have pity on me,
I never lied before; forgive me Justice,
Youth and affection stop your ears unto me.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Why do you weep? if I have spoke too harshly,
And unbeseeming my beloved Lord,
My care and duty, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O hear me,
Hear me Evanthe; I am all on torture
And this lie tears my conscience as I vent it;
I am no man.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No man for pleasure, no woman's man,

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Goodness forbid my Lord, sure you abuse yourself:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is true Evanthe;
I shame to say you will find it.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: He weeps bitterly,
It is my hard fortune, bless all young maids from it;
Is there no help my Lord in Art will comfort ye?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I hope there is.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: How long have you been destitute?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Since I was young.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: It is hard to die for nothing,
Now you shall know it is not the pleasure Sir,
(For I am compelled to love you spiritually)
That women aim at I affect ye for,
It is for your worth; and kiss me, be at peace,
Because I ever loved ye I still honoured ye,
And with all duty to my Husband follow ye;
Will ye to bed now? ye are ashamed it seems;
Pigmalion prayed and his cold stone took life,
You do not know with what zeal I shall ask Sir,
And what rare miracle that may work upon ye;
Still blush? prescribe your Law.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I prithee pardon me,
To bed, and I will sit by thee, and mourn with thee,
Mourn both our fortunes, our unhappy ones:
Do not despise me, make me not more wretched,
I pray to heaven when I am gone Evanthe,
As my poor date is but a span of time now,
To recompense thy noble patience,
Thy love and virtue with a fruitful husband,
Honest and honourable.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Come, you have made me weep now,
All fond desire die here, and welcome chastity,
Honour and chastity, do what you please Sir.

body.stage: Enter at one door Rugio, and Frier Marco, at the other door Sorano, with a little glass viol.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: What ails this piece of mischief to look sad?
He seems to weep too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Something is ahatching ,
And of some bloody nature too Lord Rugio,
This Crocodile mourns thus cunningly.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Hail holy Father,
And good day to the good Lord Rugio,
How fares the sad Prince I beseech ye Sir?

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: It is like you know, you need not ask that question,
You have your eyes, and watches on his miseries
As near as ours, I would they were as tender.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Can you do him good? as the King and you appointed him,
So he is still, as you desired I think too,
For every day he is worse (Heaven pardon all)
Put off your sorrow, you may laugh now Lord,
He cannot last long to disturb your Master,
You have done worthy service to his Brother,
And he most memorable love.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: You do not know Sir
With what remorse I ask, nor with what weariness
I groan and bow under this load of honour,
And how my soul sighs for the beastly services,
I have done his pleasures, these be witness with me,
And from your piety believe me Father,
I would as willingly unclothe myself
Of title, that becomes me not I know;
Good men, and great names best agree together;
Cast off the glorious favours, and the trappings
Of sound and honour, wealth and promises,
His wanton pleasures have flung on my weakness,
And choose to serve my Countries cause and vertues,
Poorly and honestly, and redeem my ruins,
As I would hope remission of my mischiefs.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: Old and experienced men my Lord Sorano,
Are not so quickly caught with gilt hypocrisy,
You pull your claws in now and fawn upon us,
As Lions do to entice poor foolish beasts;
And beasts we should be too if we believed ye,
Go exercise your Art.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: For heaven sake scorn me not,
Nor add more hell to my afflicted soul
Than I feele here; as you are honourable,
As you are charitable look gently on me,
I will no more to Court, be no more Devil,
I know I must be hated even of him
That was my Love now, and the more he loves me
For his foul ends, when they shall once appear to him,
Muster before his conscience and accuse him,
The fouler and the more falls his displeasure,
Princes are fading things, so are their favours.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He weeps again, his heart is touched sure with remorse.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: See this, and give me fair attention good my Lord,
And worthy Father see, within this viol
The remedy and cure of all my honour,
And of the sad Prince lies.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: What new trick is this?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: It is true, I have done Offices abundantly
Ill, and prodigious to the Prince Alphonso.
And whilst I was a knave I sought his death too.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: You are too late convicted to be good yet.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: But Father, when I felt this part afflict me,
This inward, and called me to an audit
Of my misdeeds and mischiefs --

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well, go on Sir.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: O then, then, then, what was my glory then Father?
The favour of the King, what did that ease me?
What was it to be bowed to by all creatures?
Worshipped, and courted, what did this avail me?
I was a wretch, a poor lost wretch.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Still better.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Till in the midst of all my grief I found
Repentance, and a learned man to give the means to it,
A Jew, an honest and a rare Physician,
Of him I had this Jewel; it is a Jewel,
And at the price of all my wealth I bought it:
If the King knew it I must lose my head,
And willingly, most willingly I would suffer,
A child may take it, it is so sweet in working.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To whom would you apply it to?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: To the sick Prince,
It will in half a day dissolve his melancholy.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: I do believe, and give him sleep forever .
What impudence is this, and what base malice,
To make us instruments of thy abuses?
Are we set here to poison him?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Mistake not, yet I must needs say, it is a noble care,
And worthy virtuous servants; if you will see
A flourishing estate again in Naples,
And great Alphonso reign that is truly good,
And like himself able to make all excellent;
Give him this drink, and this good health unto him.
I am not so desperate yet to kill myself,
Never look on me as a guilty man,
Nor on the water as a speedy poison:
I am not mad, nor laid out all my treasure,
My conscience and my credit to abuse ye;
How nimbly and how cheerfully it works now
Upon my heart and head, sure I am a new man
There is no sadness that I feele within me,
But as it meets it like a lazy vapour
How it flies off. Here, give it him with speed,
You are more guilty than I ever was,
And worthier of the name of evil subjects:
If but an hour you hold this from his health.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: It is some rare virtuous thing sure, he is a good man,
It must be so, come, let us apply it presently,
And may it sweetly work.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Pray let me hear on it, and carry it close my Lords.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, good Sorano.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Do my good fools, my honest pious coxcombs,
My wary fools too, have I caught your wisdoms,
You never dreamed I knew an Antidote,
Nor how to take it to secure mine own life;
I am an ass, go, give him the fine cordial,
And when you have done go dig his grave, good Frier,
Some two hours hence we shall have such a bawling,
And roaring up and down for Aquavit,
Such rubbing, and such annointing, and such cooling,
I have sent him that will make a bonfire in his belly,
If he recover it, there is no heat in Hell sure.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Podrano?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Call hither Lord Valerio, and let none trouble us.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: It shall be done Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I know he wants no additions to his tortures,
He has enough for human blood to carry,
Yet I must vex him further;
So many that I wonder his hot youth
And high-bred spirit breaks not into fury;
I must yet torture him a little further,
And make myself sport with his miseries,
My anger is too poor else. Here he comes,
Now my young married Lord, how do you feele yourself ?
You have the happiness you ever aimed at
The joy and pleasure.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Would you had the like Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You tumble in delights with your sweet Lady,
And draw the minutes out in dear embraces,
You live a right Lords life.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Would you had tried it,
That you might know the virtue but to suffer,
Your anger though it be unjust and insolent,
Sits handsomer upon you than your scorn,
To do a wilful ill and glory in it,
Is to do it double, double to be damned too.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Hast thou not found a loving and free Prince,
High in his favours too; that has conferred
Such hearts ease, and such heaps of comfort on thee,
All thou couldest ask.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You are too grown a tyrant
Upon so suffering, and so still a subject;
You have put upon me such a punishment,
That if your youth were honest it would blush at:
But you are a shame to nature, as to virtue.
Pull not my rage upon ye, it is so just,
It will give way to no respect; my life,
My innocent life, I dare maintain it Sir,
Like a wanton prodigal you have flung away,
Had I a thousand more I would allow them,
And be as careless of them as your will is;
But to deny those rights the Law has given me,
The holy Law, and make her life the penance,
Is such a studied and unheard of malice,
No heart that is not hired from Hell dare think of;
To do it then too, when my hopes were high,
High as my blood, all my desires upon me,
My free affections ready to embrace her,
And she mine own; do you smile at this, is it done well?
Is there not heaven above you that sees all?
Come hither Time, how does your noble Mistress?

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: As a Gentlewoman may do in her case that is newly married Sir:
Sickly sometimes, and fond on it, like your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She is breeding then?

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: She wants much of her colour,
And has her qualms as Ladies use to have Sir,
And her disgusts.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And keeps her chamber?

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And eats good Broths and Jellies.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: I am sure she sighs Sir, and weeps, good Lady.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Alas good Lady for it,
She should have one could comfort her Cassandra,
Could turn those tears to joys, a lusty comforter.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: A comfortable man does well at all hours,
For he brings comfortable things.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Come hither, and hold your face between, you have eaten Onions,
Her breath stinks like a Fox, her teeth are contagious,
These old women are all Elder-pipes, do ye mark me.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Yes Sir, but does your Grace think I am fit,
That am both old and virtuous.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Therefore the fitter, the older still the better,
I know thou art as holy as an old Cope,
Yet upon necessary use.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: It is true Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Her feeling sense is fierce still, speak unto her,
You are familiar;speak I say unto her,
Speak to the purpose; tell her this, and this.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Alas, she is honest, Sir, she is very honest,
And would you have my gravity --

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Aye, aye , your gravity will become the cause the better,
I will look thee out a Knight shall make thee a Lady too,
A lusty Knight, and one that shall be ruled by her;
And add to these, I will make them good, no mincing,
Nor ducking out of nicety good Lady,
But do it home, we will all be friends to tell her;
And such a joy --

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: That is it that stirs me up Sir,
I would not for the world attempt her chastity,
But that they may live lovingly hereafter.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: For that I urge it too.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: A little evil may well be suffered for a general good, Sir,
I will take my leave of your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Go fortunately, be speedy too, here comes Valerio,
If his affliction have allayed his spirit
My work has end. Come hither Lord Valerio,
How do you now?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your Majesty may guess,
Not so well, nor so fortunate as you are,
That can tie up men's honest wills and actions.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You have the happiness you ever aimed at,
The joy, and pleasure.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Would you had the like Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You tumble in delights with your sweet Lady,
And draw the minutes out in dear embraces,
You lead a right Lords life.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Would you had tried it,
That you might know the virtue but to suffer,
If anger, though it be unjust and insolent
Sits handsomer upon you than your scorn, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You clearly see now brave Valerio
What it is to be the rival to a Prince,
To interpose against a raging Lion;
I know you have suffered, infinitely suffered,
And with a kind of pity I behold it,
And if you dare be worthy of my mercy,
I can yet heal you; yield up your Evanthe,
Take off my sentence also.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I fall thus low Sir,
My poor sad heart under your feet I lay,
And all the service of my life.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Do this then, for without this it will be impossible,
Part with her for a while.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You have parted us,
What should I do with that I cannot use Sir?
