sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It is well considered, let me have the Lady,
And thou shalt see how nobly I will befriend thee,
How all this difference.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Will she come, do you think Sir?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She must be wrought, I know she is too modest,
And gently wrought, and cunningly.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is fit Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And secretly it must be done.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: As thought.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I will warrant ye, her honour shall be fair still,
No soil nor stain shall appear on that, Valerio,
You see a thousand that bear sober faces,
And show of as inimitable modesties;
You would be sworn to that, they were pure Matrons,
And most chaste maids; and yet to augment their fortunes
And get them noble friends --

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: They are content Sir,
In private to bestow their beauties on them .

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: They are so, and they are wise, they know no want for it,
Nor no eye sees they want their honesties.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If it might be carried thus.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It shall be Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will see you dead first, with this caution,
Why sure I think it might be done.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes, easily.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: For what time would your Grace desire her body?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: A month or two, it shall be carried still
As if she kept with you, and were a stranger,
Rather a hater of the Grace I offer:
And then I will return her with such honour --

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is very like I dote much on your honour.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And load her with such favour to Valerio --

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: She never shall claw off, I humbly thank ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I will make ye both the happiest, and the richest,
And the mightiest too --

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But who shall work her Sir,
For on my conscience she is very honest,
And will be hard to cut as a rough Diamond?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why you must work her, anything from your tongue,
Set off with golden and persuasive language,
Urging your dangers too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But all this time
Have you the conscience Sir to leave me nothing,
Nothing to play withal?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: There be a thousand, take where thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: May I make bold with your Queen,
She is useless to your Grace as it appears Sir,
And but a loyal wife that may be lost too;
I have a mind to her, and then it is equal?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is so Sir, thou most glorious impudence,
Have I not wrongs enough to suffer under,
But thou must pick me out to make a monster?
A hated wonder to the world? Do you start
At my entrenching on your private liberty,
And would you force a high-way through mine honour,
And make me pave it too? but that thy Queen
Is of that excellence in honesty,
And guarded with Divinity about her,
No loose thought can come near, nor flame unhallowed,
I would so right myself.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why take her to ye,
I am not vexed at this, thou shalt enjoy her,
I will be thy friend if that may win thy courtesy.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will not be your Bawd though for your Royalty.
Was I brought up, and nourished in the Court,
With thy most Royal Brother and thyself,
Upon thy Fathers charge, thy happy Fathers,
And sucked the sweetness of all human Arts,
Learnt arms and honour to become a rascal;
Was this the expectation of my youth,
My growth of honour? Do ye speak this truly,
Or do ye try me Sir? for I believe not,
At least I would not, and methinks it is impossible
There should be such a Devil in a Kings shape,
Such a malignant Fiend.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I thank ye Sir,
Tomorrow is your last day, and look to it,
Get from my sight, away.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ye are, O , my heart is too high and full to think upon ye.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: You think it fit then mortified Cassandra,
That I should be a Whore?

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Why a whore, Madam?
If every woman that upon necessity
Did a good turn, for there is the maine point, mark it,
Were termed a whore, who would be honest, Madam?
Your Lords life and your own are now in hazard,
Two precious lives may be redeemed with nothing,
Little or nothing; say an hours or days sport,
Or such a toy, the end to it is wantonness.
(That we call lust that maidens lose their fame for)
But a compelled necessity of honour,
Fair as the day,and clear as innocence,
Upon my life and conscience a direct way. --

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: To be a rascal.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: It is a kind of Rape too,
That keeps you clear, for where your will is compelled,
Though you yield up your body you are safe still.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Thou art grown a learned Bawd, I ever looked
Thy great sufficiency would break out.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: You may,
You that are young and fair scorn us old creatures,
But you must know my years ere you be wise Lady,
And my experience too; say the King loved ye?
Say it were nothing else?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Aye marry wench, now thou comest to me.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Do you think Princes favours are such sleight things,
To fling away when you please? there be young Ladies
Both fair and honourable, that would leap to reach them,
And leap aloft too.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Such are light enough;
I am no Vaulter, wench, but canst thou tell me,
Though he be a King, whether he be sound or no?
I would not give my youth up to infection.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: As sound as honour ought to be, I think Lady;
Go to, be wise, I do not bid you try him;
But if he love you well, and you neglect him,
Your Lords life hanging on the hazard of it,
If you be so wilful proud.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Thou speakest to the point still;
But when I have lain with him, what am I then, Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: What are you? why the same you are now, a Woman,
A virtuous woman, and a noble woman,
Touching at what is noble, you become so.
Had Lucrece ever been thought of, but for Tarquin?
She was before a simple unknown woman,
When she was ravished, she was a reverent Saint;
And do you think she yielded not a little?
And had a kind of will to have been re-ravished?
Believe it yes: There are a thousand stories
Of wondrous loyal women, that have slipped,
But it has been on the ice of tender honour,
That kept them cool still to the world, I think you are blessed,
That have such an occasion in your hands to beget a Chronicle,
A faithful one.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: It must needs be much honour.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: As you may make it, infinite and safe too,
And when it is done, your Lord and you may live
So quietly and peaceably together,
And be what you please.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: But suppose this, wench,
The King should so delight me with his company,
I should forget my Lord, and no more look on him.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: That is the maine hazard, for I tell you truly,
I have heard report speak, is an infinite pleasure,
Almost above belief: there be some Ladies,
And modest to the world too, wondrous modest,
That have had the blessedness to try his body,
That I have heard proclaim him a new Hercules.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: So strongly able?

sp.speaker: Cassan.
sp.l: There will be the danger,
You being but a young and tender Lady,
Although your mind be good, yet your weak body,
At first encounter too, to meet with one
Of his unconquered strength.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Peace thou rude bawd,
Thou studied old corruptness, tie thy tongue up,
Your hired base tongue; is this your timely counsel?
Dost thou seek to make me dote on wickedness?
Because it is ten times worse than thou deliverest it?
To be a whore, because he has sufficiency.
To make a hundred? O thou impudence,
Have I relieved thy age to mine own ruin?
And worn thee in my bosom to betray me?
Can years and impotence win nothing on thee
That is good and honest, but thou must go on still?
And where thy blood wants heat to sin thyself,
Force thy decrepit will to make me wicked.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: I did but tell ye.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: What the damnedest woman,
The cunningest and the skillfulest bawd comes short of:
If thou hadst lived ten ages to be damned in,
And exercised this art the Devil taught thee,
Thou couldst not have expressed it more exactly.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: I did not bid you sin.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Thou wouldest me to it,
Thou that art fit for prayer and the grave,
Thy body earth already, and corruption,
Thou taughtest the way; go follow your fine function,
There are houses of delight, that want good Matrons,
Such grave instructors, get thee thither monster,
And read variety of sins to wantons,
And when they roar with pains, learn to make plasters.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: This we have for our good wills.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: If ever I see thee more,
Or any thing that is like thee, to affright me,
By this fair light I will spoil thy bawdry,
I will leave thee neither eyes nor nose to grace thee,
When thou wantest bread, and common pity towards thee,
And art astarving in a ditch, think of me,
Then die, and let the wandering bawds lament thee;
Be gone, I charge thee, leave me.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: You will repent this.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She is angry, and the other crying too, my suit is cold;
I will make your heart ache, stubborn wench, for this;
Turn not so angry from me, I will speak to you,
Are you grown proud with your delight, good Lady,
So pampered with your sport, you scorn to know me?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I scorn ye not, I would you scorned not me, Sir,
And forced me to be weary of my duty,
I know your Grace, would I had never seen ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Because I love you, because I dote upon ye,
Because I am a man that seek to please ye.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I have man enough already to content me,
As much, as noble, and as worthy of me,
As all the world can yield.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: That is but your modesty,
You have no man, nay never look upon me,
I know it Lady, no man to content ye,
No man that can, or at the least that dare,
Which is a poorer man, and nearer nothing.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Be nobler, Sir, informed.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I will tell thee, wench,
The poor condition of this poorer fellow,
And make thee blush for shame at thine own error,
He never tendered yet a husbands duty,
To thy warm longing bed.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: How should he know that?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I am sure he did not, for I charged him no,
Upon his life I charged him, but to try him;
Could any brave or noble spirit stop here?
Was life to be preferred before affection?
Lawful, and longed for too?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Did you command him?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I did in policy to try his spirit.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: And could he be so dead cold to observe it?
Brought I no beauty? nor no love along with me?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why what is it that makes me scorn to name him?
I should have loved him, if he had ventured for it,
Nay, doted on his bravery.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Only charged?
And with that spell sit down? dare men fight bravely
For poor slight things, for drink or ostentation?
And there endanger both their lives and fortunes,
And for their lawful Loves fly off with fear?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It is true, and with a cunning base fear too to abuse thee;
Made thee believe, poor innocent Evanthe,
Wretched young girl, it was his impotency;
Was it not so? deny it.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: O my anger, at my years to be cozened with a young man!

sp.speaker: Fred,
sp.l: A strong man too, certain he loved ye dearly.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: To have my shame and love mingled together,
And both flung on me like a wait to sink me,
I would have died a thousand times.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: So would any,
Any that had the spirit of a man;
I would have been killed in your arms.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I would he had been,
And buried in mine arms, that had been noble,
And what a monument would I have made him?
Upon this breast he should have slept in peace,
Honour, and everlasting love his mourners;
And I still weeping till old time had turned me,
And pitying powers above into pure crystal.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Hadst thou loved me, and had my way been stuck
With deaths, as thick as frosty nights with stars,
I would have ventured.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Sure there is some trick in it; Valerio never was coward.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Worse than this too,
Tamer, and seasoning of a baser nature,
He set your woman on ye to betray ye,
Your bawdy woman, or your sin solicitor:
I pray but think what this man may deserve now,
I know he did, and did it to please me too.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Good Sir afflict me not too fast, I feele
I am a woman, and a wronged one too,
And sensible I am of my abuses,
Sir, you have loved me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And I love thee still, pity thy wrongs, and dote upon thy person.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: To set my woman on me it was too base Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Abominable vild.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: But I shall fit him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: All reason and all Law allows it to ye,
And ye are a fool, a tame fool, if you spare him.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: You may speak now, and happily prevail too,
And I beseech your Grace be angry with me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I am at heart. She staggers in her faith,
And will fall off I hope, I will ply her still.
Thou abused innocence, I suffer with thee
If I should give him life, he would still betray thee;
That fool that fears to die for such a beauty,
Would for the same fear sell thee unto misery?
I do not say he would have been bawd himself too.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Followed thus far? nay then I smell the malice,
It tastes too hot of practised wickedness,
There can be no such man, I am sure no Gentleman:
Shall my anger make me whore, and not my pleasure?
My sudden inconsiderate rage abuse me?
Come home again, my frighted faith, my virtue,
Home to my heart again: he be a bawd too?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I will not say, he offered fair Evanthe.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Nor do not dare, it will be an impudence,
And not an honour for a Prince to lie;
Fie Sir, a person of your rank to trifle,
I know you do lie.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Lie shamefully, and I could wish myself a man but one day,
To tell you openly you lie too, basely.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Take heed wild fool.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Take thou heed thou tame Devil,
Thou all Pandora's box in a Kings figure,
Thou hast almost whored my weak belief already,
And like an Engineer blown up mine honour;
But I shall countermine, and catch your mischief,
This little Fort you seek, I shall man nobly,
And strongly too, with chaste obedience
To my dear Lord, with virtuous thoughts that scorn ye.
Victorious Tameris never won more honour
In cutting off the Royal head of Cyrus,
Than I shall do in conquering thee; farewell,
And if thou canst be wise, learn to be good too,
It will give thee nobler lights then both thine eyes do;
My poor Lord and myself are bound to suffer,
And when I see him faint under your sentence,
I will tell ye more, it may be then I will yield too.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Fool, unexampled, shall my anger follow thee?

body.stage: Enter Rugio, and Fryer Marco, amazed.

sp.speaker: Rugio.
sp.l: Cursed on our sights, our fond credulities,
A thousand curses on the slave that cheated us.
The damned slave.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We have even shamed our service,
Brought our best care and loyalties to nothing,
It is the most fearful poison, the most potent,
Heaven give him patience; o it works most strongly,
And tears him Lord.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: That we should be so stupid,
To trust the arrantest villain that ever flattered,
The bloodiest too, to believe a few soft words from him,
And give way to his prepared tears.

sp.speaker: Alphonso
sp.l: O, O, o.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: Hark Fryer Marco, hark, the poor Prince, that we should be such blockheads,
As to be taken with his drinking first?
And never think what Antidotes are made for?
Two wooden sculls we have, and we deserve to be hanged for it;
For certainly it will be laid to our charge;
As certain too, it will dispatch him speedily,
Which way to turn, or what to. --

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let us pray, Heavens hand is strong.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: The Poison is strong, you would say.
sp.stage: Enter Alphonso, carried in a Coach by two Fryers.
sp.l: Would anything -- He comes, let us give him comfort.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Give me more air, air, more air, blow,blow,
Open thou Eastern gate, and blow upon me,
Distill thy cold dews, O thou icy Moon,
And rivers run through my afflicted spirit,
I am all fire, fire, fire, the raging dog star
Rains in my blood, o which way shall I turn me?
Aetna and all his flames burn in my head,
Fling me into the Ocean or I perish:
Dig, dig, dig, till the springs fly up,
The cold, cold springs, that I may leap into them,
And bathe my scorched limbs in their purling pleasures;
Or shoot me up into the higher Region,
Where treasures of delicious snow are nourished,
And banquets of sweet hail.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: Hold him fast Fryer, O how he burns!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: What will ye sacrifice me?
Upon the Altar lay my willing body?
And pile your wood up, fling your holy incense?
And as I turn me you shall see all flame,
Consuming flame, stand off me, or you are ashes.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Most miserable wretches.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Bring hither charity
And let me hug her, Fryer, they say she is cold,
Infinite cold, devotion cannot warm her;
Draw me a river of false lovers tears
Clean through my breast, they are dull, cold, and forgetful,
And will give ease, let Virgins sigh upon me,
Forsaken souls, the sighs are precious,
Let them all sigh: o hell, hell, hell, o horror.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To bed, good Sir.

sp.speaker: Alpho.
sp.l: My bed will burn about me,
Like Phaeton, in all consuming flashes
I am enclosed , let me fly, let me fly, give room;
Betwixt the cold bear, and the raging Lion
Lies my safe way; O for a cake of ice now,
To clap unto my heart to comfort me;
Decrepit winter hang upon my shoulders,
And let me wear thy frozen Icicles
Like Jewels round about my head, to cool me;
My eyes burn out, and sink into their sockets,
And my infected brain like brimstone boils,
I live in hell, and several furies vex me;
O carry me where no Sun ever showed yet
A face of comfort, where the earth is crystal,
Never to be dissolved, where nought inhabits
But night and cold, and nipping frosts, and winds
That cut the stubborn rocks, and make them shiver;
Set me there friends.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: Hold fast, he must to bed Fryer, what scalding sweats he has?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He will scald in hell for it, that was the cause.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Drink, drink, a world of drink,
Fill all the cups, and all the antic vessels,
And borrow pots, let me have drink enough,
Bring all the worthy drunkards of the time,
The experienced drunkards, let me have them all,
And let them drink their worst, I will make them Idiots,
I will lie upon my Back and swallow Vessels;
Have Rivers made of cooling wine run through me,
Not stay for this man's health, or this great Princes,
But take an Ocean, and begin to all; o, o.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He cools a little, now away with him,
And to his warm bed presently.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No drink? no wind?no cooling air?

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: You shall have anything.
His hot fit lessens, Heaven put in a hand now,
And save his life; there is drink Sir in your chamber,
And all cool things.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Away, away, let us fly to them.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: To say you were impotent, I am ashamed on it,
To make yourself no man, to a fresh maid too,
A longing maid, upon her wedding night also,
To give her such a door.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I prithee pardon me.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Had you been drunk, it had been excusable,
Or like a Gentleman under the Surgeons hands,
And so not able, there had been some colour,
But wretchedly to take a weakness to ye,
A fearful weakness, to abuse your body,
And let a lie work like a spell upon ye,
A lie, to save your life.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Will you give me leave sweet?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: You have taken too much leave, and too base leave too,
To wrong your Love; hast thou a noble spirit?
And canst thou look up to the peoples loves,
That call thee worthy, and not blush Valerio?
Canst thou behold me that thou hast betrayed thus?
And no shame touch thee?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Shame attend the sinful, I know my innocence.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Never think to face it, that is a double weakness,
And shows thee falser still; the King himself,
Though he be wicked, and our Enemy,
But juster than thine, in pity of my injuries,
Told me the truth.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What did he tell Evanthe?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: That but to gain thy life a fortnight longer,
Thy loved poor life, thou gavest up all my duties.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I swear it is false, my life and death are equal,
I have weighed them both, and find them but one fortune,
But Kings are men, and live as men, and die too,
Have the affections men have, and their falsehoods;
Indeed they have more power to make them good;
The King is to blame, it was to save thy life wench,
Thy innocent life, that I forbore thy bed,
For if I had touched thee thou hadst died, he swore it.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: And was not I as worthy to die nobly?
To make a story for the times that follows,
As he that married me? what weakness, Sir,
Or disability do you see in me,
Either in mind or body? to defraud me
Of Such an opportunity? Do you think I married you
Only for pleasure, or content in lust?
To lull you in mine arms, and kiss you hourly?
Was this my end? I might have been a Queen, Sir,
If that had caught me, and have known all delicates;
There is few that would have shunned so fair an offer,
O thou unfaithful fearful man, thou hast killed me,
In saving me this way, thou hast destroyed me,
Robbed me of that thy love can never give more;
To be unable to save me? O misery!
Had I been my Valerio, thou Evanthe,
I would have lain with thee under a Gallows,
Though the Hangman had been my Hymen, and the furies
With iron whips and forks, ready to torture me,
I would have hugged thee too, though hell had gaped at me
Save my life! that expected to die bravely,
That would have wooed it too? Would I had married
An Eunuch, that had truly no ability,
Than such a fearful liar, thou hast done me
A scurvy courtesy, that has undone me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will do no more, since you are so nobly fashioned,
Made up so strongly,I will take my share with ye,
Nay Dear, I will learn of you.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: He weeps too tenderly;
My anger is gone, good my Lord pardon me,
And if I have offended, be more angry,
It was a woman's flash, a sudden valour,
That could not lie concealed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I honour ye by all the rights of holy marriage,
And pleasures of chaste love, I wonder at ye,
You appear the vision of a Heaven unto me,
Stuck all with stars of honour shining clearly,
And all the motions of your mind celestial;
Man is a lump of earth, the best man spiritless,
To such a woman; all our lives and actions
But counterfeits in Arras to this virtue;
Chide me again, you have so brave an anger,
And flows so nobly from you, thus delivered,
That I could suffer like a child to hear ye,
Nay make myself guilty of some faults to honour ye.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I will chide no more, you have robbed me of my courage.
And with a cunning patience checked my impudence;
Once more forgiveness?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Will this serve Evanthe?
And this my love? Heavens mercy be upon us;
But did he tell no more?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Only this trifle: You set my woman on me, to betray me;
It is true, she did her best, a bad old woman,
It stirred me Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I cannot blame thee, Jewel.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: And methought when your name was sounded that way --

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He that will spare no fame, will spare no name Sweet;
Though as I am a man, I am full of weakness,
And may slip happily into some ignorance,
Yet at my years to be a bawd, and cozen
Mine own hopes with my Doctrine --

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I believe not, nor never shall; our time is out tomorrow .

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Let us be tonight then full of fruitfulness,
Now we are both of one mind, let us be happy,
I am no more a wanting man Evanthe,
Thy warm embraces shall dissolve that impotence,
And my cold lie shall vanish with thy kisses;
You hours of night be long, as when Alemena
Lay by the lusty side of Jupiter;
Keep back the day, and hide his golden beams,
Where the chaste watchful morning may not find them;
Old doting Tython hold Aurora fast,
And though she blush the day-break from her cheeks,
Conceal her still; thou heavy Walne stand firm,
And stop the quicker revolutions;
Or if the day must come, to spoil our happiness,
Thou envious Sun peep not upon our pleasure,
Thou that all Lovers curse, be far off from us.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Then let us to bed, and this night in all joys
And chaste delights --

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Stay, I must part ye both;
It is the Kings command, who bids me tell ye,
Tomorrow is your last hour.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I obey, Sir,
In Heaven we shall meet, Captain, where King Frederick
Dare not appear to part us.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Mistake me not, though I am rough in doing of my Office,
You shall find, Sir, you have a friend to honour ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I thank ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Pray Captain tell the King,
They that are sad on Earth, in Heaven shall sing.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: Have you writ to the Captain of the Castle?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, and charged him
Upon his souls health, that he be not cruel,
Told him Valerio's worth among the people,
And how it must be punished in posterity,
Though he scape now.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: But will not he, Fryer Marco betray this to the King?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Though he be stubborn, and of a rugged nature, yet he is honest,
And honours much Valerio.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: How does Alphonso?
For now methinks my heart is light again,
And pale fear fled.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He is as well as I am;
The Rogue against his will has saved his life,
A desperate poison has re-cured the Prince.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: To me it is most miraculous.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To me too, till I consider why it should do so,
And now I have found it a most excellent Physic,
It wrought upon the dull cold misty parts,
That clogged his soul, which was another poison,
A desperate too, and found such matter there,
And such abundance also to resist it,
And wear away the dangerous heat it brought with it,
The pure blood and the spirits scaped untainted.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: It was Heavens high hand, none of Sorano's pity.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Most certain it was, had the malicious villain
Given him a cooling poison,he had paid him.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: The Captain of the Castle.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O ye are welcome, how does your Prisoner?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: He must go for dead;
But when I do a deed of so much villainy,
I will have my skin pulled over mine ears, my Lord,
Though I am the Kings, I am none of his abuses;
How does your Royal Charge? that I might see once.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I pray see now, you are a trusty Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Good Fathers, I thank Heaven, I feele no sickness,

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: He speaks again.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Nothing that bars the free use of my spirit,
Methinks the air is sweet to me, and company
A thing I covet now Castruchio.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Sir, he speaks, and knows, for Heaven sake break my pate Lord,
That I may be sure I sleep not.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Thou wert honest.
Ever among the rank of good men counted,
I have been absent long out of the world,
A dream I have lived, how does it look Castruchio?
What wonders are abroad?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I fling off duty to your dead Brother, for he is dead in goodness,
And to the living hope of brave Alphonso,
The noble heir of nature, and of honour,
I fasten my Allegiance.

sp.speaker: Mar,
sp.l: Softly Captain, we dare not trust the air with this blessed secret,
Good Sir, be close again, heaven has restored ye,
And by miraculous means, to your fair health,
And made the instrument your enemies malice,
Which does prognosticate your noble fortune;
Let not our careless joy lose you again, Sir,
Help to deliver ye to a further danger,
I pray you pass in, and rest a while forgotten,
For if your brother come to know you are well again,
And ready to inherit as your right,
Before we have strength enough to assure your life,
What will become of you? and what shall we
Deserve in all opinions that are honest,
For our loss of judgment, care, and loyalty?

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: Dear Sir, pass in, Heaven has begun the work,
And blessed us all, let our endeavours follow,
To preserve this blessing to our timely uses,
And bring it to the noble end we aim at;
Let our cares work now, and our eyes pick out
An hour to show ye safely to your Subjects,
A secure hour.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I am counselled; ye are faithful.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Which hour shall not be long, as we shall handle it.
Once more the tender of my duty.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Thank ye.

sp.speaker: Castr.
sp.l: Keep you the Monastery.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: Strong enough I will warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: Who are all these that crowd about the Court Fool?
Those strange new faces?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: They are Suitors Coxcomb,
Dainty fine Suitors to the widow Lady,
Thou hadst best make one of them, thou wilt be hanged as handsomely
At the Months end, and with as much joy followed,
And it were tomorrow; as many mourning bawds for thee,
And holy Nuns, whose vestal fire never vanishes,
In sackcloth smocks, as if thou wert Heir apparent
To all the impious Suburbs, and the sink-holes.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: Out you base rogue.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Why dost abuse thyself,
Thou art to blame, I take thee for a Gentleman,
But why does not thy Lord and Master marry her?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: Why, she is his sister.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: It is the better Fool,
He may make bold with his own flesh and blood,
For on my conscience there is none else will trust him,
Then he may pleasure the King at a dead pinch too,
Without a Mephestophilus, such as thou art,
And engross the royal disease like a true Subject.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: Thou wilt be whipped.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: I am sure thou wilt be hanged,
I have lost a Ducat else, which I would be loath to venture
Without certainty. They appear.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: Why these are rascals.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: They were meant to be so, does thy Master deserve better kindred?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: There is an old Lawyer,
Trimmed up like a Galley Foist,what would he do with her?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: As Usurers do with their Gold, he would look on her,
And read her over once a day, like a hard report,
Feed his dull eye, and keep his fingers itching;
For anything else, she may appeal to a Parliament,
Sub Pena's and Post Kaes have spoiled his Codpiece;
There is a Physician too, older than he,
And Gallen Gallenatius, but he has lost his spurs,
He would be nibbling too.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: I marked the man, if he be a man.

sp.speaker: Foole
sp.l: Has much ado to be so,
Cerecloths and Syrups glue him close together,
He would fall apieces else; mending of she patients,
And then trying whether they be right or no,
In his own person, there is the honest care if it,
Has mollified the man; if he do marry her,
And come but to warm him well at Cupids bonfire,
He will bulge so subtly and suddenly,
You may snatch him up by parcels, like a Sea Rack:
Will your Worship go, and look upon the rest, Sir?
And hear what they can say for themselves.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: I will follow thee.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: You tell us wonders.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: But I tell you truths, they are both well.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Why are not we in Arms then?
And all the Island given to know --

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Discreetly and privately it must be done, it will miss else,
And prove our ruins; most of the noble Citizens
Know it by me, and stay the hour to attend it,
Prepare your hearts and friends, let theirs be right too,
And keep about the King to avoid suspicion;
When you shall hear the Castle Bell, take courage,
And stand like men, away, the King is coming .

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Now Captain, what have you done with your Prisoner?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: He is dead, Sir, and his body flung in the Sea,
To feed the fishes, it was your will, I take it,
I did it from a strong Commission,
And stood not to capitulate.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It is well done,
And I shall love you for your faith. What anger
Or sorrow did he utter at his end?

sp.speaker: Castr.
sp.l: Faith little, Sir, that I gave any ear to,
He would have spoke, but I had no Commission
To argue with him, so I flung him off;
His Lady would have seen, but I locked her up,
For fear her woman's tears should hinder us.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It was trusty still. I wonder, my Sorano,
We hear not from the Monastery; I believe
They gave it not, or else it wrought not fully.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Did you name the Monastery?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes, I did Captain.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I saw the Fryer this morning, and Lord Rugio,
Bitterly weeping, and wringing of their hands,
And all the holy men hung down their heads.

sp.speaker: Sora.
sp.l: It is done, I will warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I asked the reason.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What answer hadst thou?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: This in few words, Sir,
Your Brother is dead, this morning he deceased,
I was your servant, and I wept not, Sir,
I knew it was for your good.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It shall be for thine too,
Captain, indeed it shall. O my Sorano,
Now we shall live.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Aye , now there is none to trouble ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Captain, bring out the woman, and give way
To any Suitor that shall come to marry her,
Of what degree soever.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: It shall be done, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: O let me have a lusty Banquet after it,
sp.stage: Enter Evanthe, Camillo, Cleanthes, Menallo, Fool, Castruchio.
sp.l: I will be high and merry.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: There be some Lords
That I could counsel ye to fling from Court, Sir,
They pry into our actions, they are such
The foolish people call their Countries honours,
Honest brave things, and style them with such Titles;
As if they were the patterns of the Kingdom,
Which makes them proud, and prone to look into us,
And talk at random of our actions,
They should be your lovers of your commands;
And followers of your will; bridles and curbs
To the hard headed Commons that malign us,
They come here to do honour to my sister,
To laugh at your severity, and fright us;
If they had power, what would these men do?
Do you hear, Sir, how privily they whisper?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I shall silence them,
And to their shames within this week Sorano,
In the mean time have patience.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: How they jeer, and look upon me as I were a Monster?
And talk and jeer, How I shall pull your plumes, Lords
How I shall humble ye within these two days,
Your great names, nor your Country cannot save ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let in the Suitors. Yet submit, I will pardon ye,
You are half undone already, do not wind
My anger to that height, it may consume ye.
And utterly destroy thee, fair Evanthe: yet I have mercy.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Use it to your bawds,
To me use cruelty, it best becomes ye,
And shows more Kingly: I contemn your mercy,
It is a cozening, and a bawdy mercy;
Can anything be hoped for, to relieve me?
Or is it fit? I thank you for a pity, when you have killed my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Who will have her?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: My tears are gone,
My tears of love to my dear Valerio,
But I have filled mine eyes again with anger;
O were it but so powerful to consume ye,
My tongue with curses I have armed against ye,
With Maiden curses, that Heaven crowns with horrors,
My heart set round with hate against thy tyranny;
O would my hands could hold the fire of Heaven,
Wrapped in the thunder that the Gods revenge with,
That like stern Justice I might fling it on thee;
Thou art a King of Monsters, not of men,
And shortly thou wilt turn this Land to Devils.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I will make you one first, and a wretched Devil,
Come, who will have her?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: I if it like your Majesty, I am a Lawyer,
I can make her a Jointure of any man's Land in Naples,
And she shall keep it too, I have a trick for it.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Canst thou make her a Jointure of thine honesty?
Or thy ability, thou lewd abridgement?
Those are non-suited and flung over the bar.

sp.speaker: Physitian.
sp.l: If it please your Majesty to give me leave,
I dare accept her; and though old I seem, Lady,
Like Eason, by my art I can renew youth and ability.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: In a powdering Tub
Stew thyself tender again, like a Cock Chicken,
The broth may be good, but the flesh is not fit for dogs sure;

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Lady, take me, and I will maintain thine honour,
I am a poor Captain, as poor people call me,
Very poor people, for my Soldiers
They are quartered in the outsides of the City,
Men of ability, to make good a high way;
We have but two grand Enemies that oppose us,
The Don Gout, and the Gallows.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: I believe ye, and both these you will bind her for a Jointure;
Now Seignior firk.

sp.speaker: Cut-purse.
sp.l: Madam, take me and be wise,
I am rich and nimble, and those are rare in one man,
Every man's pocket is my Treasury,
And no man wears a Suit but fits me neatly;
Clothes you shall have, and wear the purest Linen,
I have a tribute out of every Shop, Lady,
Meat you shall eat, I have my Caters out too,
The best and lustiest, and drink good Wine, good Lady,
Good quickening Wine, Wine that will make you caper,
And at the worst --

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: It is but capering short, Sir,
You seldom stay for Agues or for Surfeits,
A shaking fit of a whip sometimes over takes ye,
Marry you die most commonly of chokings,
Obstructions of the halter are your ends ever;
Pray leave your horn and your knife for her to live on.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Poor wretched people, why do you wrong yourselves?
Though I feared death, I should fear you ten times more,
You are every one a new death, and an odious,
The earth will purify corrupted bodies,
You will make us worse, and stink eternally.
Go home, go home, and get good Nurses for you,
Dream not of wives.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You shall have one of them, if they dare venture for ye.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: They are dead already,
Crawling diseases that must creep into
The next grave they find open, are these fit husbands
For her you have loved Sir, though you hate me now,
And hate me mortally, as I hate you,
Your nobleness in that you have done otherwise,
And named Evanthe once as your poor Mistress,
Might offer worthier choice.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Speak, who dare take her for one month, and then die?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Die Sir?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Aye , die Sir, that is the condition.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: One month is too little
For me to repent in for my former pleasure,
To go still on, unless I were sure she would kill me,
And kill me delicately before my day,
Make it up a year, for by that time I must die,
My body will hold out no longer.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No Sir, it must be but a month.

sp.speaker: Lawy.
sp.l: Then farewell Madam,
This is like to be great year of dissension
Among good people, and I dare not lose it,
There will be money got.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Bless your good Ladyship, there is nothing in the grave but bones and ashes,
In Taverns there is good wine, and excellent wenches,
And Surgeons while we live.

sp.speaker: Cutp.
sp.l: Adieu sweet Lady,
Lay me when I am dead near a rich Alderman,
I cannot pick his Purse, no,I will no dying,
Though I steal Linen, I will not steal my shroud yet.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Send ye a happy march.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: And you all halters, you have deserved them richly
These do all Villainies, an mischiefs of all sorts, yet those they fear not
To flinch where a fair wench is at the stake.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Come, your sentence, let me die, you see Sir,
None of your valiant men dare venture on me,
A month is a dangerous thing.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Away with her, let her die instantly.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Will you then be willing
To die at the time prefixed, that I must know too,
And know it beyond doubt.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What if I did wench?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: On that condition if I had it certain,
I would be your anything, and you should enjoy me,
How ever in my nature I abhor you,
Yet as I live I would be obedient to you;
But when your time came how I should rejoice,
How then I should bestir myself to thank ye
To see your throat cut, how my heart would leap Sir,
I would die with you, but first I would so torture ye,
And cow you in your end, so despise you,
For a weak and wretched coward, you must end sure;
Still make ye fear, and shake, despised, still laugh at ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Away with her, let her die instantly.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Stay, there is another, and a Gentleman,
His habit shows no less, may be his business
Is for this Ladies love.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Say why ye come Sir, and what you are.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am descended nobly, a Prince by birth, and by my trade a Soldier,
A Princes fellow, Abidig brought me forth,
My Parents Duke Agenor, and fair Egla,
My Parents Duke Agenor and fair Egla,
My business hither to renew my love
With a young noble spirit, called Valerio;
Our first acquaintance was at Sea, in fight
Against a Turkish man of War, a stout one,
Where Lion-like I saw him show his valour,
And as he had been made of complete virtue,
Spirit, and sire, no dregs of dull earth in him.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Thou art a brave Gentleman, and bravely speakest him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The Vessel dancing under him for joy,
And the rough whistling winds becalmed to view him;
I saw the child of honour, for he was young,
Deal such an Alms amongst the spiteful pagans,
His towering sword flew like an eager Falcon,
And round about his reach invade the Turks,
He had entrenched himself in his dead quarries;
The silver Crescents on the tops they carried
Shrank in their heads to see his rage so bloody,
And from his fury suffered sad eclipses;
The game of death was never played more nobly,
The meagre thief grew wanton in his mischiefs,
And his shrunk hollow eyes smiled on his ruins.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Heaven keep this Gentleman from being a Suitor,
For I shall never deny him, he is so noble.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But what can last long? strength and spirit wasted,
And fresh supplies flew on upon this Gentleman,
Breathless and weary with oppression,
And almost killed with killing, it was my chance
In a tall Ship I had to view the fight;
I set into him, entertained the Turk.
And for an hour gave him so hot a breakfast,
He clapped all linen up he had to save him,
And like a Lovers thought he fled our fury;
There first I saw the man I loved, Valerio,
There was acquainted, there my soul grew to him,
And his to me, we were the twins of friendship.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Fortune protect this man, or I shall ruin him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I made this voyage to behold my friend,
To warm my love a new at his affection;
But since I landed, I have heard his fate:
My Fathers had not been to me more cruel,
I have lamented too, and yet I keep
The treasure of a few tears for you Lady,
For by description you were his Evanthe.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Can he weep that is a stranger to my story?
And I stand still and look on? Sir, I thank ye;
If noble spirits after their departure,
Can know, and wish, certain his soul gives thanks too;
There are your tears again, and when yours fail Sir,
Pray ye call to me, I have some store to lend ye. Your name?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Urbino.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: That, I may remember,
That little time I have to live, your friendships,
My tongue shall study both.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Do you come hither, only to tell this story Prince Urbino?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My business now is, Sir, to woo this Lady.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Blessing defend ye; Do you know the danger?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes, and I fear it not, danger is my play-fellow,
Since I was man it has been my best companion,
I know your doom, it is for a Month you give her,
And then his life you take that marries her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It is true, nor can your being born a Prince,
If you accept the offer, free you from it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I not desire it, I have cast the worst,
And even that worst to me is many blessings;
I loved my friend, not measured out by time,
Nor hired by circumstance of place and honour,
But for his wealthy self and worth I loved him,
His mind and noble mold he ever moved in,
And woe his friend because she was worthy of him,
The only relic that he left behind, Sir;
To give his ashes honour, Lady take me,
And in me keep Valerio's love alive still,
When I am gone, take those that shall succeed me,
Heaven must want light, before you want a husband,
To raise up Heirs of love and noble memory,
To your unfortunate --

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Am I still hated? hast thou no end, O fate, of my affliction?
Was I ordained to be a common Murderess?
And of the best men too? Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Peace Sweet, look on my hand.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I do accept the Gentleman, I faint with joy.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I stop it, none shall have her, convey this stranger hence.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am no stranger. -- Hark to the bell, that rings,
Hark, hark, proud Frederick, that was King of mischief.
Hark, thou abhorred man, dost thou hear thy sentence?
Does not this bell ring in thine ears thy ruin?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What bell is this?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The Castle bell: Stand sure Sir, and move not, if you do you perish.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: It rings your knell; Alphonso, King Alphonso.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Alphonso, King Alphonso.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I am betrayed, lock fast the Palace.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: We have all the keys, Sir.
And no door here shall shut without our Licence.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Do you shake now Lord Sorano? no new trick?
Nor speedy poison to prevent this business?
No bawdy meditation now to fly to?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Treason, Treason, Treason.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yes, we hear ye,
sp.stage: Enter Alphonso, Rugio, Marco, Castruchio, Queen, with Guard.
sp.l: And we have found the Traitor in your shape, Sir,
We will keep him fast too.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: recovered! then I am gone,
The Sun of all my pomp is set and vanished.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Have you not forgot this face of mine, King Frederick?
Brother I am come to see you, and have brought
A Banquet to be merry with your Grace;
I pray sit down, I do beseech your Majesty
And eat, eat freely, Sir, why do you start?
Have you no stomach to the meat I bring you?
Dare you not taste? have ye no Antidotes?
You need not fear; Sorano is a good Apothecary,
Methinks you look not well, some fresh wine for him,
Some of the same he sent me by Sorano;
I thank you for it, it saved my life, I am bound to ye,
But how it will work on you -- I hope your Lordship
Will pledge him too, Methinks you look but scurvily,
And would be put into a better colour,
But I have a candied Toad for your good Lordship.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Would I had anything that would dispatch me,
So it were down, and I out of this fear once.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Sir, Thus low as my duty now compels me,
I do confess my unbounded sins, my errors,
And feele within my soul the smarts already;
Hide not the noble nature of a brother,
The pity of a friend, from my afflictions;
Let me a while lament my misery,
And cast the load off of my wantonness,
Before I find your fury, then strike home,
I do deserve the deepest blow of Justice,
And then how willingly, O death,I will meet thee.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Rise, Madam, those sweet tears are potent speakers,
And brother live, but in the Monastery,
Where I lived, with the self same silence too,
I will teach you to be good against your will brother,
Your tongue has done much harm, that must be dumb now;
The daily pilgrimage to my fathers Tomb,
Tears, sighs, and groans, you shall wear out your days with,
And true ones too, you shall perform dear brother;
Your diet shall be slender to enforce these; too light a penance, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I do confess it.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Sorano you shall --

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: How he studies for it,
Hanging is the least part of my penance certain.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: What Lady is that that kneels?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: The chaste Evanthe.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Sweet, your petition?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: It is for this bad man, Sir,
Abominable bad, but yet my brother.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: The bad man shall attend as bad a Master,
And both shall be confined within the Monastery;
His rank flesh shall be pulled with daily fasting,
But once a week he shall smell meat, he will surfeit else,
And his immodest mind compelled to prayer;
On the bare boards he shall lie, to remember
The wantonness he did commit in beds;
And drink fair water, that will never inflame him;
He saved my life, though he purposed to destroy me,
For which I will save his, though I make it miserable:
Madam, at Court I shall desire your company,
You are wise and virtuous, when you please to visit
My brother Frederick, you shall have our Licence,
My dear best friend, Valerio.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Save Alphonso.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Long live Alphonso, King of us, and Naples.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Is this the Lady that the wonder goes on?
Honoured sweet maid, here take her my Valerio,
The King now gives her, she is thine own without fear:
Brother, have you so much provision that is good?
Not seasoned by Sorano and his Cooks?
That we may venture on with honest safety,
We and our friends?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: All that I have is yours, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Come then, let us in, and end this Nuptial,
Then to our Coronation with all speed:
My virtuous maid, this day I will be your Bride-man,
And see you bedded to your own desires too;
Beshrew me Lords, who is not merry hates me,
Only Sorano shall not bear my cup:
Come, now forget old pains and injuries,
As I must do, and drown all in fair healths;
That Kingdom is blessed, where the King begins
His true love first, for there all loves are twins.
You are welcome Gentlemen, and would our Feast
Were so well seasoned, to please every Guest;
Ingenuous appetites, I hope we shall,
And their examples may prevail in all
(Our noble friends) who writ this, bid me say,
He had rather dress, upon a Triumph day,
My Lord Mayors Feast, and make him Sauces too,
Sauce for each several mouth, nay further go,
He had rather build up those invincible Pies
And Castle Custards that affright all eyes,
Nay eat them all, and their Artillery,
Then dress for such a curious company
One single dish; yet he has pleased ye too,
And you have confessed he knew well what to do;
Be hungry as you were wont to be, and bring
Sharpe stomachs to the stories he shall sing,
And he dare yet, he says, prepare a Table
Shall make you say well dressed, and he well able.
We have your favours Gentlemen, and you
Have our endeavours, dear friends grudge not now,
There is none of you, but when you please can sell
Many a lame Horse, and many a fair tale tell;
Can put off many a maid unto a friend,
That was not so since the action at Mile-end;
Ours is a Virgin yet, and they that love
Untainted flesh, we hope our friends will prove.

body.stage: Here endeth A Wife for a Month.
